title: ~게다가 [gedaga] (Moreover, besides)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to introduce an additional point or detail which strengthens the previous statement.
long_explanation: `~게다가 [gedaga]` is a conjunction in Korean language. It is used to provide further information or details on top of a previously mentioned point. The word is similar to 'moreover' or 'besides' in English. It is typically used for adding extra reasons or justifications about why a certain action or situation occurred or a certain decision was made. Unlike 'and', '~게다가 [gedaga]' hints that the following information is an additional or further detail rather than a separate point.

examples.kr: 그 카페는 커피 맛이 아주 좋게다가 분위기도 좋아서 자주 가요.
examples.romaji: Geu kape-neun keopi masi aju joheu-ge-da-ga bun-wi-gi-do jo-a-seo ja-ju ga-yo.
examples.en: I often go to that cafe because, besides the coffee being really good, the atmosphere is also nice.

examples.kr: 오늘은 비가 오게다가 추워서 나가기 싫어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul-eun bi-ga o-ge-da-ga chu-wo-seo na-ga-gi si-reo-yo.
examples.en: Today, it's raining and, besides, it's cold so I don't want to go out.

examples.kr: 그는 성격이 참 좋게다가 똑똑해서 사람들이 많이 좋아해요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun seong-gyeog-i cham jo-ge-da-ga ttokttokhaeseo sa-ram-deul-i ma-ni jo-a-hae-yo.
examples.en: He has a very good personality and, moreover, he is smart, so many people like him.

examples.kr: 이 식당은 음식이 맛있게다가 가격도 저렴해서 자주 찾아가요.
examples.romaji: I sikdang-eun eumsik-i masit-ge-da-ga gyeog-do jeo-ryeom-hae-seo ja-ju cha-ja-ga-yo.
examples.en: The food at this restaurant is delicious and, in addition, the prices are cheap, so I visit often.

title: ~거니와 [geoniwa] (And, besides)
short_explanation: Used to express multiple reasons or explanations, equivalent to 'and' or 'besides' in English.
long_explanation: '~거니와 [geoniwa]' is a conjunctive particle in Korean that is used to connect clauses, indicating the addition of another explanation, reason or narrative. It is often used when the speaker wants to provide two or more reasons, explanations or situations simultaneously. The function of this particle is similar to 'and' or 'besides' in English.

examples.kr: 이것은 비싼 거니와 내가 원하는 모양이 아니에요.
examples.romaji: Igeoseun bissan geoniwa naega wonhaneun moyang-i anieyo.
examples.en: This is not only expensive but also not the style that I want.

examples.kr: 그 사람은 도움을 주기는 커녕, 오히려 방해만 하더라고요.
examples.romaji: Geu saram-eun doumeul jugineun keonnyeong, ohiryeo banghaeman hadeoragoyo.
examples.en: That person not only didn't help but actually hindered.

examples.kr: 나는 책을 읽는 것이 좋아하는 거니와, 영화도 좋아해서 주말에는 항상 바빠요.
examples.romaji: Naneun chaegeul ilgneun geosi joahaneun geoniwa, yeonghwado joahaseo jumalen hangsang bappayo.
examples.en: Not only do I enjoy reading books, but I also like movies, so I am always busy on weekends.

examples.kr: 이 상품은 품질이 낮은 거니와, 서비스도 엉망이에요.
examples.romaji: I sangpumeun pumjili najeun geoniwa, seobiseudo eongmang-ieyo.
examples.en: This product has poor quality, and besides, the service is also a mess.

title: ~것 마는 [geot maneun] (But)
short_explanation: This construction is used to express a contrast or contradiction, similar to 'but' in English.
long_explanation: The '~것 마는 [geot maneun]' construction in the Korean language is similar to the conjunction 'but' in English. It presents a contrasting or contradictory idea following the first part of a sentence. Typically, the event or action described in the first part of the sentence does not bring about the expected result because of the scenario introduced by the '~것 마는' construction, creating a sense of contrast or contradiction.
formation: Verb/Adjective in past tense + -ㄴ/은/는 + 것 + 마는

examples.kr: 그녀는 공부를 열심히 했는데 학교에서 점수가 좋지 않은 것 마는 저는 이해할 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun gongbureul yeolsimhi haetneunde hakgyoeseo jeomsuga jotji anheun geot maneun jeoneun ihaehal su eopsseoyo.
examples.en: She studied hard, but I can't understand why her scores in school are not good.

examples.kr: 어젯밤에 잠을 많이 잤는데 아직도 피곤한 것 마는 이해하기 어려워요.
examples.romaji: Eojjeotbame jameul manhi jassneunde ajikdo pigonhan geot maneun ihaehagi eoryeowoyo.
examples.en: I slept a lot last night, but it's hard to understand why I'm still tired.

examples.kr: 우리 팀이 열심히 노력했는데 게임에서 지는 것 마는 너무 아쉬워요.
examples.romaji: Uri timi yeolsimhi noryeokhaetneunde geimeseo jineun geot maneun neomu ashuwoyo.
examples.en: Our team worked hard, but it's such a shame that we lost in the game.

examples.kr: 나는 매일 운동을 했는데 체중이 늘어난 것 마는 실망스러워요.
examples.romaji: Naneun maeil undongeul haetneunde chejungi neureonan geot maneun silmangseureowoyo.
examples.en: I exercised every day, but I'm disappointed that my weight has increased.

title: ~과/와 같이 [gwa/wa gachi] (Like, as if)
short_explanation: Used to express a comparison, similarity or analogy; 'like', 'as if'.
long_explanation: '~과/와 같이 [gwa/wa gachi]' is a frequently used expression in Korean that conveys a sense of comparison, similarity or analogy. It is equivalent to saying 'like' or 'as if' in English. You can use it when you want to compare two different things, situations, or events or if you want to describe something as if it's something else for better visualization and explanation.

examples.kr: 지난 주말에는 봄과 같이 따뜻했어요, 하지만 이번 주말은 겨울과 같이 너무 추웠어요.
examples.romaji: Jinan jumal-eneun bomgwa gachi ttatteushaess-eoyo, hajiman ibeon jumal-eun gyeoulgwa gachi neomu chuweoss-eoyo.
examples.en: Last weekend was warm like spring, but this weekend was as cold as winter.

examples.kr: 그 그림은 사진과 같이 생생해요, 그러니까 그가 대단한 화가라는 것을 알 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geu geurim-eun sajingwa gachi saengsaenghaeyo, geuleonikka geuga daedanhan hwaga laneun geos-eul al su iss-eoyo.
examples.en: That painting is vivid like a photograph, so you can see that he is a great artist.

examples.kr: 오늘은 여름과 같이 더웠어요, 그래서 아이스크림을 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul-eun yeoleumgwa gachi deowoss-eoyo, geulaeseo aiseukeulim-eul meog-eoss-eoyo.
examples.en: Today was hot like summer, so I ate ice cream.

examples.kr: 독서는 운동과 같아요, 마음을 건강하게 해주는 운동이죠.
examples.romaji: Dogseo-neun undonggwa gat-ayo, ma-eum-eul geonganghage haejuneun undong-ijyo.
examples.en: Reading is like exercise, a workout that keeps the mind healthy.

title: ~나마저 [namajeo] (Even)
short_explanation: Used to express a sense of surprise or amazement; 'even'.
long_explanation: '~나마저 [namajeo]' is a postposition used in Korean to express a sense of surprise or amazement, equivalent to 'even' in English. This expression is used to emphasize that the subject or object is unexpected in the context, portraying that it surpasses the usual expectation or boundary.

examples.kr: 그녀는 학교에서 가장 어려운 수업도 쉽게 이해하는데, 이 수업나마저 이해하는 걸 보아서는 그녀 정말 대단해요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun hakgyoeseo gajang eoryeoun sueobdo swipge ihaehaneunde, i sueobnamajeo ihaehaneun geol boaseoneun geunyeo jeongmal daedanhaeyo.
examples.en: She easily understands even the hardest classes in school, seeing her understand this class as well, she's truly amazing.

examples.kr: 나는 보통 친구들과 잘 지내지만, 그 친구나마저 저를 싫어하는 것 같아서 상처받았어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun botong chingudeulgwa jal jinaejiman, geu chingunamajeo jeoreul silheohaneun geot gataseo sangcheobadasseoyo.
examples.en: I usually get along well with friends, but I was hurt because it seems like even that friend dislikes me.

examples.kr: 다른 사람들은 다 반대했지만, 그는 한 사람이라도 지지하는 중요성을 알았다. 그런데 그 사람나마저 반대하자 기분이 나빴어요.
examples.romaji: Dareun saramdeureun da bandaehaetjiman, geuneun han saramirado jijihaneun jungyoseongeul alatda. Geureonde geu saramnamajeo bandaehaja gibuni nappeosseoyo.
examples.en: Other people all opposed, but he knew the importance of having even one person support. But when even that person opposed, he felt bad.

examples.kr: 책상 위에 있는 모든 물건들을 보았는데, 그 물건나마저 찾지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Chaeksang wie issneun modeun mulgeondeureul boassneunde, geu mulgeonnamajeo chatji moshaesseoyo.
examples.en: I looked at every single item on the desk, but I couldn't find even that item.

title: ~뿐만 아니라 [ppunman anira] (Not only... but also)
short_explanation: Used to express 'Not only... but also'.
long_explanation: '~뿐만 아니라 [ppunman anira]' is a conjunctive adverb in Korean that is used when you want to express the meanings 'not only... but also'. It helps provide additional information about the subject or the event in the sentence. It signifies that not only the described event or condition applies, but there is additional information that must be noted.

examples.kr: 그녀는 중국어뿐만 아니라 일본어도 유창하게 할 수 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun junggugeoppunman anira ilbon-eodo yuchanghage hal su itsseumnida.
examples.en: She is not only fluent in Chinese but can also speak Japanese fluently.

examples.kr: 나는 공부뿐만 아니라 운동도 좋아한다.
examples.romaji: Naneun gongbuppunman anira undongdo joahanda.
examples.en: I not only like studying, but I also like exercising.

examples.kr: 이 상품은 가격이 저렴뿐만 아니라 품질도 뛰어나다.
examples.romaji: I sangpumeun gakyeogi jeoryeomppunman anira pumjildo ttwieonada.
examples.en: This product is not only affordable but also of high quality.

examples.kr: 그는 한국어뿐만 아니라 영어도 유창하게 구사할 수 있어서 통역으로 일하고 있다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun hangugeoppunman anira yeong-eodo yuchanghage gusahal su iss-eoseo tong-yeogeulo ilhago issda.
examples.en: Not only can he speak Korean fluently, but he also speaks fluent English, so he is working as an interpreter.

title: ~더니만 [deoniman] (After, and then)
short_explanation: Used to connect two clauses, indicating that the second happened or was realized after the first.
long_explanation: '~더니만' is a conjunction used in Korean to connect two clauses or actions, expressing that the second occurred or came to be realized after the first. It implies that the speaker witnessed or experienced the first situation, and then the second situation happened or came to light. This grammar point is often used in storytelling or sharing experiences, to convey a sequence of events or actions.

examples.kr: 저는 이것을 먹었더니만 맛이 진짜 변했어요. 그래서 다른 음식을 찾아 마시기로 했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun igeoseul meogeosseodeoniman masi jinjja byeonhaesseoyo. Geuraeseo dareun eumsigeul chaja masigi sijakhaesseoyo.
examples.en: After I ate this, the taste really changed. So, I decided to look for another food to eat.

examples.kr: 나는 그녀에게 전화했더니만 그녀는 휴가를 가서 전화를 못 받았어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun geunyeoege jeonhwahaessdeoniman geunyeoneun hyugareul gaseo jeonhwaleul mot badasseoyo.
examples.en: After I called her, it turns out she went on vacation and couldn't answer the phone.

examples.kr: 서점에 갔더니만 내가 원하는 책은 이미 다 팔렸어요. 그래서 다른 서점에서 찾아야 했어요.
examples.romaji: Seojeome gassdeoniman naega wonhaneun chaegeneun imi da pallyeosseoyo. Geuraeseo dareun seojeomeseo chajaya haesseoyo.
examples.en: After I went to the bookstore, it turns out the book I wanted was already sold out. So, I had to find it in another bookstore.

examples.kr: 피자집에 갔더니만 주문하려는 피자는 이미 전부 다 소진되었어요. 이런 경우는 처음이에요.
examples.romaji: Pijajibe gassdeoniman jumunharyeoneun pijaneun imi jeonbu da sojindugyeossneoyo. ireon gyeonguneun cheoeumieyo.
examples.en: After I went to the pizza shop, it turns out the pizza I wanted to order was already completely sold out. This was a first for me.

title: ~이든지 ~든지 [ideunji deunji] (Whether… or)
short_explanation: Used to present multiple alternatives; 'whether...or'.
long_explanation: '~이든지 ~든지 [ideunji deunji]' is a grammar point used in Korean to indicate the alternatives options or possibilities. Similar to 'whether...or' in English, it lists two or more possibilities and conveys a meaning of indifference towards which option is chosen. This structure is often used in interrogative sentences or statements of assumption.

examples.kr: 당신이 커피를 좋아하든지, 차를 좋아하든지, 이 카페에서는 모두를 만족시킬 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Dangsin-i keopi-reul joh-ahadeunji, cha-reul joh-ahadeunji, i kape-eseoneun modu-reul manjogshil su iss-eoyo.
examples.en: Whether you like coffee or tea, this cafe can satisfy everyone.

examples.kr: 아침에 일찍 나가든지, 저녁에 늦게 돌아오든지, 매일 한 시간 동안 만나기로 약속해요.
examples.romaji: Achim-e iljjik nagadeunji, jeonyeog-e neutge dol-aodeunji, maeil han shigan dong-an mannagilo yaksoghaeyo.
examples.en: Whether you leave early in the morning or come back late in the evening, we promise to meet for an hour every day.

examples.kr: 햄버거를 좋아하든지, 피자를 좋아하든지, 이 식당은 모든 음식을 제공할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Hambaeg-eo-reul joh-ahadeunji, pijareul joh-ahadeunji, i sikdang-eun modeun eumsig-eul jegonghal su iss-eoyo.
examples.en: Whether you like hamburgers or pizza, this restaurant can provide all types of food.

examples.kr: 당신이 평일에 여행 가든지, 주말에 가든지, 무관하게 편하게 여행을 즐기세요.
examples.romaji: Dangsin-i pyeongil-e yeohaeng gadeunji, jumal-e gadeunji, mugwanhage pyeonhage yeohaeng-eul jeulgiseyo.
examples.en: Whether you go traveling on weekdays or on the weekend, enjoy your trip comfortably without any restrictions.

title: ~임에 틀림없다 [ime tteollimeopda] (Without a doubt)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used when you are certain about something. It translates to 'without a doubt' or 'it's certain that' in English.
long_explanation: '~임에 틀림없다 [ime tteollimeopda]' is a Korean phrase expressing a high degree of certainty about a situation or event. It is primarily used when the speaker wishes to emphasize the indisputability of an assertion or the inevitability of a certain outcome. This phrase is commonly used in formal situations or written texts, owing to its rather formal and emphatic connotation.
formation: Verb + 기/Verb stem + 음/아니라고 하기 + 에 틀림없다

examples.kr: 그의 출연이 성공적이었다라고 말하기에는 너무 이른 상황이지만, 그의 재능은 분명 임에 틀림없다.
examples.romaji: Geuui chulyeoni seonggongjeogieossdara-go malhagineun neomu irin sanghwang-ijiman, geuui jaeneung-eun bunmyeong im-e teullim-eobsda.
examples.en: While it's too early to say that his performance was successful, it's without a doubt that his talent is evident.

examples.kr: 우리 팀이 이길 확률이 높기 때문에, 우리 가 이겨낼 것임에 틀림없다.
examples.romaji: Uri timi igil hwagru-i nopgi ttamun-e, uri-ga igyeonael geosim-e tteullim-eobsda.
examples.en: Because our team has a high probability of winning, it is certain that we will win.

examples.kr: 그는 비록 다른 사람들에게 비판받을지라도 그의 선택이 옳았음에 틀림없다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun birok dareun saramdeulege bipanbadeuljirado geuui seontaegi olhassime tteollimeopda.
examples.en: Even though he may be criticized by others, it is certain that his decision was correct.

examples.kr: 내일 비가 올 것임에 틀림없다, 관측소의 예보에 따르면.
examples.romaji: Naell biga ol geosime tteollimeopda, gwanchuksoye yeboe ddeulamyeon.
examples.en: It will without a doubt rain tomorrow, according to the weather station's forecast.

title: ~쩌면 [jjeomyeon] (Maybe, perhaps)
short_explanation: Used to express the possibility or probability; 'maybe', 'perhaps'.
long_explanation: '~쩌면 [jjeomyeon]' is an adverbial ending used in Korean expressing the speaker's uncertainty about the situation and implying that there might be a possibility. This can be translated to 'maybe' or 'perhaps' in English. Usually placed at the beginning of the sentence, it throws a sense of doubt or assumption to the whole sentence, indicating the speaker’s suspicion or probability.

examples.kr: 쩌면 그는 진심으로 당신을 사랑하는 거였을지도 몰라요.
examples.romaji: Jjeomyeon geuneun jinsimeuro dangsineul saranghaneun geoyeosseuljido mollayo.
examples.en: Perhaps he really loved you.

examples.kr: 쩌면 이 갈등은 해결될 수 있을지도 모르는 일이라고 생각해요.
examples.romaji: Jjeomyeon i galdungeun haegyeoldoel su isseuljido moreuneun irirago saenggakhaeyo.
examples.en: Maybe, this conflict could possibly be resolved.

examples.kr: 쩌면 그 계획이 성공할 수 있을지도 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Jjeomyeon geu gyehoegeun seonggonghal su isseuljido moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: Perhaps that plan could succeed.

examples.kr: 쩌면 이번 시험은 제일 어려울 수도 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jjeomyeon ibeon siheomeun jeil eoryeoul sudo isseoyo.
examples.en: This exam might possibly be the most difficult.

title: ~치고는 [chigoneun] (For, considering)
short_explanation: Expresses the meaning of 'for' or 'considering'. Used when the situation or condition is better or worse than expected.
long_explanation: '~치고는 [chigoneun]' is a postposition used in Korean to indicate a comparison or contrast. It is used to express the meaning of 'for' or 'considering', stating a condition and presenting an outcome that is better or worse than expected given that condition. It often implies surprise at that outcome, as the result doesn't match common expectations.

examples.kr: 그가 어린애치고는 너무 많은 책을 읽어서 놀랐어요.
examples.romaji: Geuga eorinaechigoneun neomu manheun chaegeul ilgeoseo nollasseoyo.
examples.en: I was surprised that he, for a young child, reads so many books.

examples.kr: 팀장치고는 너무 책임감이 없어서 모두가 기분이 나빴어요.
examples.romaji: Timjangchigoneun neomu chaegimgami eopseoseo moduga gibuni nappeosseoyo.
examples.en: Everyone was upset because he, for a team leader, lacks responsibility.

examples.kr: 첫날치고는 너무 많은 고객들이 왔고 우리는 정말로 바빴어요.
examples.romaji: Cheotnalchigoneun neomu manheun gogaekdeuli wasgo urineun jeongmallo babbeosseoyo.
examples.en: For the first day, too many customers came and we were really busy.

examples.kr: 그녀는 몸이 작은 편인데, 작은 체격치고는 꽤 힘세다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun momi jakgeun pyeoninde, jageun chegyeokchigoneun kkwae himseda.
examples.en: She has a small body, but for her small stature, she is quite strong.

title: ~커녕 [keonyeong] (Far from, let alone)
short_explanation: Used to express a gap between expectation and reality, equivalent to 'far from' or 'let alone' in English.
long_explanation: '~커녕 [keonyeong]' is a Korean grammar point used to convey a gap between an expectation and the actual reality. It is often used to show that not only did the expected result not happen, but the opposite or something even less did. In English, it is similar to the expression 'far from' or 'let alone'.

examples.kr: 계획은 잘 하겠다고 했는데 시작하지 커녕, 준비조차도 못 했어요.
examples.romaji: Gyehoegeun jal hagetdago haessneunde sijakhaji keonyeong, junbijochado mot haesseoyo.
examples.en: He said he would plan well, but far from starting, he couldn't even prepare.

examples.kr: 약속 시간에 늦지 않을 거라고 생각했는데, 일찍 오기커녕 늦게 와버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Yaksok sigane neujji anheul georago saenggakhaessneunde, iljjik ogikeonyeong neuje gwa beoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: I thought he would not be late for the appointment time, but far from coming early, he came late.

examples.kr: 공부하러 도서관에 오긴 왔는데, 독서커녕 졸다가 하루가 다 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Gongbuhareo doseogwane ogin watneunde, dokseokeonyeong joldaga haruga da gasseoyo.
examples.en: I did come to the library to study, but my day went by snoozing, let alone reading.

examples.kr: 세일에 간다고 기대했지만, 싸게 살 생각은 커녕 더 비싸게 살게 됐어요.
examples.romaji: Seire gandago gidaehaetjiman, ssage sal saenggageun keonyeong deo bissage salge dwaesseoyo.
examples.en: I was expecting a sale, but far from buying cheap, I ended up spending more.

title: ~판에 [pane] (In the midst of)
short_explanation: ~판에 [pane] is used to express the situation during a certain event or action.
long_explanation: '판에 [pane]' is a grammar pattern that is used to express that something is happening in the midst of a situation or action. The literal translation would be 'on the board of', but it could be better understood as 'in the midst of' or 'during'. This grammar point can be used with both nouns and action verbs with the '는' modifier. It's noteworthy to mention that '판에' tends to be used in more formal or written Korean.

examples.kr: 학교가 시작된 판에 새로운 학생이 학교에 입학하였습니다.
examples.romaji: Hakgyoga sijakdoen pane saeroun haksaengi hakgyoe ibhakhaessseubnida.
examples.en: A new student entered the school in the midst of the school year starting.

examples.kr: 회사가 오늘부터 폐업하게 되는 판에 저는 새로운 직장을 찾고 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Hoesaga oneulbuteo pyeophage doeneun pane jeoneun saeroun jikjangeul chatgo issseubnida.
examples.en: I am looking for a new job in the midst of the company closing down starting today.

examples.kr: 주요 사업을 준비하고 있는 판에 회사의 주식이 급등하였습니다.
examples.romaji: Juyo saeobeul junbihago issneun pane hoesaui jusigi geupdeunghaessseubnida.
examples.en: The company's stock shot up in the midst of preparing for a major business.

examples.kr: 시험공부를 하는 판에 친구들이 놀러왔습니다.
examples.romaji: Siheomgongbureul haneun pane chingudeuli nolleowassseubnida.
examples.en: My friends came to play in the midst of me studying for the exam.

title: ~하건마는 [hageonmaneun] (But, however)
short_explanation: Used to express contrast or opposition; 'but', 'however'.
long_explanation: '~하건마는 [hageonmaneun]' is a conjunction used in Korean to suggest contrast or opposition between the preceding and the following clauses. It's equivalent to 'but' or 'however' in English. It conveys a sense of disagreement or difference in opinions, actions, or situations; often used to introduce a contrasting point or idea that may contradict or conflict with the previous statement.

examples.kr: 난 그래픽 디자인을 공부하건마는 컴퓨터를 잘 못 다뤄서 디자인 프로그램 사용이 어려운 것 같아.
examples.romaji: Nan geuraepik dijaineul gongbuhageonmaneun keompyuteoreul jal mot darweoseo dijain peurogeuraem sayongi eoryeoun geot gata.
examples.en: I study graphic design, but I'm not good at handling computers, so I think it's difficult to use design programs.

examples.kr: 오늘 날씨가 좋아서 산책하려고 했건마는 갑자기 비가 와서 산책할 수 없었어.
examples.romaji: Oneul nalssiga johaseo sancaekharyeogo haetgeonmaneun gabjagi biga waseo sancaekhal su eopseosseo.
examples.en: The weather was good today, so I was going to take a walk, but suddenly it rained, so I couldn't walk.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 잘하고 싶건마는 단어 외우기가 너무 어려워서 매일 공부해도 잘 생각나지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeoreul jalhago sipgeonmaneun daneo oewoogiga neomu eoryeowoseo maeil gongbuhadaedo jal saenggaknaji anhayo.
examples.en: I want to be good at Korean, but memorizing words is so difficult that even if I study every day, I can't remember well.

examples.kr: 친구가 나에게 생일 선물을 주기로 했건마는 그는 선물을 잊어버려서 아무것도 주지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga naege saengil seonmureul jugiro haetgeonmaneun geuneun seonmureul ijeobeoryeoseo amugeotdo juji anhasseoyo.
examples.en: My friend promised to give me a birthday present, but he forgot to give the gift and didn't give me anything.

title: ~하더라도 [hadeorado] (Even if)
short_explanation: Used to express the meaning of 'even if', 'even though', or 'despite'.
long_explanation: The '~하더라도 [hadeorado]' matrificial construction is used in Korean grammar to convey the English equivalent of 'even if' or 'even though'. It gives more emphasis to the sentence and is used to express a hypothetical condition or a contrastive situation. It is often used in sentences to indicate a situation or an action that may happen in the future or a hypothetical scenario., It is also used to express a situation or action contrary to the expected or normal conditions. '~하더라도 [hadeorado]' can be used with all types of verbs.

examples.kr: 비가 오더라도 우산을 가져가지 않을 거예요, 제가 우산을 싫어해서요.
examples.romaji: Biga odeorado usaneul gajyeogaji anheul geoyeyo, jegauusaneul silheohaseyo.
examples.en: Even if it rains, I won't take an umbrella because I don't like umbrellas.

examples.kr: 피곤하더라도 공부를 계속해야 해요, 시험이 곧 있어서요.
examples.romaji: Pigonhadeoradogongbureul gyesokhaeya haeyo, siheomi got itsseoseoyo.
examples.en: Even if I'm tired, I have to keep studying because the exam is soon.

examples.kr: 일찍 일어나야 하더라도 항상 운동을 해야 돼요, 건강을 위해서요.
examples.romaji: Ichik ireonara haryeodeorado hangsang undongeul hae dwaeyo, geongang-eul wihaseoyo.
examples.en: Even if I have to get up early, I always have to exercise for my health.

examples.kr: 시간이 없더라도 저는 부지런히 한국어를 계속 공부해야 합니다, 저는 한국어에 관심이 많아서요.
examples.romaji: Sigani oepseorado jeoneun buzireonhi hangugeoreul gyesok gongbuhaeya habnida, jeoneun hangugeo-e gwansimi manh-aseo.
examples.en: Even if I don't have time, I have to keep diligently studying Korean because I have a lot of interest in Korean.

title: ~하든지 말든지 [hadeunji maldeunji] (Whether... or not)
short_explanation: Used to convey 'whether... or not'.
long_explanation: '~하든지 말든지 [hadeunji maldeunji]' is a compound ending used to express an indifference towards two or more possible choices or actions, conveying the similar meaning as 'whether...or not' in English. It implies that the outcome will not change no matter the choices made.

examples.kr: 그 사람이 좋아하든지 말든지 우리는 계획대로 진행하겠어요.
examples.romaji: Geu sarami joahadeunji maldeunji urineun gyeongwaekdaero jinhaenghagesseoyo.
examples.en: Whether that person likes it or not, we will proceed according to plan.

examples.kr: 오늘 비가 오든지 말든지 우리는 계속해서 산책할 계획이에요.
examples.romaji: Oneul biga odeunji maldeunji urineun gyesokhaeseo sancaekhal gyeongiraeeo.
examples.en: Whether or not it rains today, we plan to keep walking.

examples.kr: 네가 참여하든지 말든지 이 파티는 계속될 것이다.
examples.romaji: Nega chamyeohadeunji maldeunji i patineun gyesokdoel geosida.
examples.en: Whether you participate or not, this party will continue.

examples.kr: 그녀가 나를 사랑하든지 말든지 나는 그녀를 계속해서 사랑할거야.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga naleul salanghadeunji maldeunji naneun geunyeoleul gyesoghaeseo salanghalgeoya.
examples.en: Whether she loves me or not, I will continue to love her.

title: ~하려니와 [haryeoniwa] (Trying to, but)
short_explanation: Used to express a situation where one is trying to do something, but it's difficult or can't be done.
long_explanation: '~하려니와 [haryeoniwa]' is a Korean grammar point used to express a situation where one is trying to do something but there's an obstacle or an issue preventing it from happening. It can be translated as 'trying to, but' or 'want to, but' in English.

examples.kr: 오늘은 친구들과 함께 영화를 보러 가려니와, 갑자기 날씨가 너무 안 좋아져서 계획이 실패했어요.
examples.romaji: Oneuleun chingudeulgwa hamkke yeonghwareul boreo garyeoniwa, gapjagi nalssiga neomu an johajyeoseo gyehoeki silpaehaesseoyo.
examples.en: I was trying to go watch a movie with my friends today, but the weather suddenly got so bad that our plan failed.

examples.kr: 좀 더 다양한 맛의 음식을 만들어 보려니와, 요리 실력이 부족해서 잘 되지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Jom deo dayanghan matsui eumsigeul mandeureo boryeoniwa, yori silryeogi bujokhaeseo jal doeji anhayo.
examples.en: I tried to make food with more diverse flavors, but it didn't go well because my cooking skills are lacking.

examples.kr: 빨리 잠자려니와, 많은 생각들이 계속 머리를 스쳐 지나가서 잠에 들지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Ppalli jamjaryeoniwa, manheun saenggakdeuli gyesok meorireul seuchyeo jinagaseo jame deulji moshaesseoyo.
examples.en: I tried to fall asleep quickly, but I couldn’t because many thoughts kept passing through my mind.

examples.kr: 운동을 시작하려니와, 집에 있느라 시간을 못 내어서 아직 시작하지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Undongeul sijakharyeoniwa, jibe issneura siganeul mot naeoseo ajik sijakhaji moshaesseoyo.
examples.en: I tried to start exercising, but I couldn't find the time because I was at home, so I haven't started yet.

title: ~하여간 [hayaegane] (Anyway, anyhow)
short_explanation: Used to express the speaker's willing or desire to do something regardless of the circumstances.
long_explanation: '~하여간 [hayaegane]' is a grammar point used in Korean to show the speaker's strong determination or willingness to do something regardless of any factors or obstacles. It is often used in sentences where the speaker is expressing their resolve to complete a certain action or reach a particular conclusion, regardless of difficulties or oppositions. This is similar to 'anyway' or 'anyhow' in English.

examples.kr: 시험을 준비하지 않았지만, 노력하여간 시험을 통과하려고 합니다.
examples.romaji: Siheomeul junbijianhatjiman, noryeoghaeyagan siheomeul tonggwuharyeogo hamnida.
examples.en: Although I didn't prepare for the exam, I will try to pass the exam anyhow.

examples.kr: 비록 경제적으로 어려운 상황이지만, 아끼려하여간 학비를 모아야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Birog gyeongjejeogeuro eoryeoun sanghwangijiman, akgiryeohaeyagan hakbireul moaya hamnida.
examples.en: Even though it's a financially difficult situation, I must save for my tuition fees anyway.

examples.kr: 힘들어도, 꾸준히하였하간 그 목표를 달성할 수 있을 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Himdeureodo, kkujunihaesseossneun hayagan geu mokpyoreul dalssengal su isseul geosimnida.
examples.en: Although it's hard, if you persist anyhow, you will be able to achieve that goal.

examples.kr: 많은 자금이 필요하지만, 아껴 사용하여간 꿈을 이뤄낼 수 있을 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Manheun jagumi pil-yohajiman, akkyeo sayonghaeagan kkumeul irwonaelsu isseul geosimnida.
examples.en: Though a lot of money is required, by spending frugally anyway, you will be able to fulfill your dream.

title: ~하여야만 [hayeoyaman] (Only when)
short_explanation: This is used to indicate that a certain condition must be satisfied in order for something else to happen.
long_explanation: '~하여야만 [hayeoyaman]' is a grammar point in Korean that is used when a certain condition or criteria must be met for something else to occur. It's equivalent to 'only when' in English. It stresses the singularness of the condition and is often used to tell someone what they should do in order for something to happen, or to describe a prerequisite.

examples.kr: 일찍 기상하여야만 출근시간에 도착할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Iljjik gisanghayeoyaman chulgooksigane dochakhal su isseoyo.
examples.en: I can only arrive at work on time if I get up early.

examples.kr: 당신의 결장을 받아들여주신 의사와 상의하여야만 수술 계획을 변경할 수 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Dangsineui gyeoljangeul badadeulyeojusin uisawa sangyihayeoyaman susul gyehoekul byeongyeokhal su issseubnida.
examples.en: Only when you consult with the doctor who accepted your case can you change the surgery plan.

examples.kr: 고정적인 수입이 있어야만 주택대출을 받을 수 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Gojeongjeogin suipi isseoyaman jutakdaechurul badul su issseubnida.
examples.en: Only when you have a regular income can you get a housing loan.

examples.kr: 훈련에 잘 따라하여야만 시험에 합격 할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Hunlyene jal ttarahayeoyaman siheome hapgyeok hal su isseoyo.
examples.en: Only when you follow the training well can you pass the exam.

title: ~해야겠다 [haeyagetda] (Should, ought to)
short_explanation: Used to express the speaker's intention or determination to do something in the future.
long_explanation: '~해야겠다 [haeyagetda] ' is a grammar pattern usually used in Korean to express a person's feeling of necessity, determination to do something or make a decision about a future action. This form describes the speaker’s intent to do something or that something 'should' be done, mentioned in an affirmative tone. Commonly paired with verbs in the future tense.

examples.kr: 이제 늦었으니까 집에 가야겠다.
examples.romaji: Ije neujeosseunikka jibe gayagetda.
examples.en: Now that it's late, I should go home.

examples.kr: 내일 시험이 있으니까 오늘 밤에 공부해야겠다.
examples.romaji: Naeil siheomi isseunikka oneul bame gongbuhaeyagetda.
examples.en: I have an exam tomorrow, so I should study tonight.

examples.kr: 체중이 계속 증가하고 있어서 운동을 시작해야겠다.
examples.romaji: Chejungi gyesok jeunggahago isseoseo undongeul sijakhaeyagetda.
examples.en: My weight continues to increase, so I should start exercising.

examples.kr: 오래동안 연락하지 않아서 친구에게 전화해야겠다.
examples.romaji: Oraedongan yeollakaji anhaseo chinguege jeonhwahaeyagetda.
examples.en: I haven't been in touch for a long time, so I should call my friend.

title: ~에 근거하여 [e geungeohayeo] (Based on)
short_explanation: Used to express the notion 'based on', 'according to', 'in accordance with'.
long_explanation: ~에 근거하여 [e geungeohayeo] is a Korean grammar point used to indicate the source or basis of an information, action, or conclusion. It translates to 'based on', 'according to', or 'in accordance with' in English, and usually linked to facts, rules, laws or authoritative sources. It indicates that the statement or action is derived from, or because of the referenced base.

examples.kr: 데이터에 근거하여, 이 제품이 가장 잘 팔렸습니다.
examples.romaji: Dateo-e geungeohayeo, i jepumeun gajang jal pallyeotsseumnida.
examples.en: Based on the data, this product sold the best.

examples.kr: 법에 근거하여, 그는 잘못되었다는 것이 증명되었습니다.
examples.romaji: Beop-e geungeohayeo, geuneun jalmosdwaessdaneun geosi jeungmyeongdwaetseumnida.
examples.en: Based on the law, it was proven that he was wrong.

examples.kr: 과학적 연구에 근거하여, 지구 온난화는 심각한 문제입니다.
examples.romaji: Gwahakjeok yeongu-e geungeohayeo, jigu onnanhwaneun simgakhan munje-ibnida.
examples.en: Based on scientific research, global warming is a serious problem.

examples.kr: 그녀의 후기에 근거하여, 이 식당은 맛이 좋지 않다고 합니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoui hugi-e geungeohayeon, i sikdangeun mas-i joji anhdago hamnida.
examples.en: Based on her review, this restaurant doesn't taste good.

title: ~에 비추어 볼 때 [e bichueo bol ttae] (In comparison to)
short_explanation: Used to express comparison; 'In comparison to', 'Compared to'.
long_explanation: '~에 비추어 볼 때 [e bichueo bol ttae]' is a compound verb form used to express comparison between two factors or subjects in Korean. It is a phrasal expression used to compare one thing with another, to assert a judgement or conclusion about something relative to something else. It conveys a sense of contrast as well, akin to 'in comparison to' or 'compared to' in English.
formation: Noun + 에 비추어 볼 때 + Verb

examples.kr: 우리나라에 비추어 볼 때 미국의 문화는 매우 다릅니다.
examples.romaji: Urinarae bichueo bol ttae miguk-ui munhwa-neun ma-eu dareum-nida.
examples.en: Compared to our country, American culture is very different.

examples.kr: 나의 과거에 비추어 볼 때 나는 많이 변했어요.
examples.romaji: Na-ui gwageoe bichueo bol ttae, naneun mani byeonhaesseoyo.
examples.en: Compared to my past, I have changed a lot.

examples.kr: 서울에 비추어 볼 때 부산은 훨씬 조용하다.
examples.romaji: Seoule bichueo bol ttae, busaneun hwolssin joyonghada.
examples.en: Compared to Seoul, Busan is much quieter.

examples.kr: 다른 사람들에 비추어 볼 때 그는 특히 뛰어납니다.
examples.romaji: Dareun saramdeule bichueo bol ttae, geuneun teughi ttwieonamnida.
examples.en: Compared to other people, he is particularly outstanding.

title: ~이다 보니 [ida boni] (Since, as)
short_explanation: This pattern is used to state a reason or cause that leads to certain result, acting like 'since' or 'as' in English.
long_explanation: '~이다 보니 [ida boni]' is a conjunction phrase used in Korean to express a cause-and-effect relationship, often aligning with 'since' or 'as' in English. It is used when a certain state or repeated action leads to a certain consequence or realisation. This grammar point often implies that the effect was gradual or not immediately apparent, unravelling over time. Similar idiomatic English phrases might be 'as time went on' or 'over time'.

examples.kr: 매일 같은 길을 걸어다니니 보니 이 동네에 대해 잘 알게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Maeil gateun gileul georeodanini boni i dongne-e daehae jal alge doeeoss-eoyo.
examples.en: Since I walk the same way every day, I have come to know this neighborhood well.

examples.kr: 한국에서 한 달 살다 보니 한국어가 조금 더 편해졌어요.
examples.romaji: Hangug-eseo han dal salda boni hanguk-eoga jogeum deo pyeonhae-jyeoss-eoyo.
examples.en: Since living in Korea for a month, Korean has become a bit more comfortable for me.

examples.kr: 우리는 같은 회사에서 일하다 보니 친해졌어요.
examples.romaji: Ulineun gateun hoesa-eseo ilhada boni chinhae-jyeoss-eoyo.
examples.en: Since we worked together at the same company, we became close.

examples.kr: 매일 아침에 운동을 하다 보니 몸이 건강해진 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Maeil achim-e undong-eul hada boni mom-i geonganghae-jin geos gat-ayo.
examples.en: Since I exercise every morning, it seems my body has become healthier.

title: ~이라면 그것은 [iramyeon geugeoseun] (If it’s called)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used when you describe or explain something in detail if it's called a certain way or if it's defined as something.
long_explanation: The term '~이라면 그것은 [iramyeon geugeoseun]' is a compositional grammar point in Korean that is typically utilized in the defining or explaining of a subject. It is roughly equivalent to 'If it's called...' in English. In essence, it is a method of introducing, defining, or explaining something if it's referred to or defined in a particular way. It often precedes a more detailed or comprehensive description of a particular subject matter.

examples.kr: 사랑이라면 그것은 상대방을 배려하고 이해해 주는 것을 말한다.
examples.romaji: Sarangiramyeon geugeoseun sangdaebangeul baeryeohago ihaehaejuneun geoseul maldanda.
examples.en: If it's called love, it means showing care and understanding towards the other person.

examples.kr: 자유라면 그것은 자신의 생각과 말을 제한받지 않는 것이다.
examples.romaji: Jayuramyeon geugeoseun jasinui saenggakwa malul jehanbadji antneun geosida.
examples.en: If it's called freedom, it means not having your thoughts and words restricted.

examples.kr: 친구라면 그것은 서로를 이해하고 도와주는 사이를 말한다.
examples.romaji: Chinguramyeon geugeoseun seororeul ihaehago dowajuneun saireul maldanda.
examples.en: If it's called a friend, that refers to a relationship where you understand each other and provide help.

examples.kr: 성공이라면 그것은 목표를 달성하고 자신의 꿈을 이룬 것을 말한다.
examples.romaji: Seonggongiramyeon geugeoseun mokpyoreul dalhagong jasinui kkumeul irun geoseul maldanda.
examples.en: If it's called success, it refers to achieving your goals and fulfilling your dreams.

title: ~이래 [irae] (Since then, after)
short_explanation: Used to express 'since then' or 'after'.
long_explanation: '~이래 [irae]' is a Korean grammar point that denotes 'since then' or 'after.' It is used to express time, referencing an event or occurrence in the past and its continued effect or relevance to the present situation. It emphasizes the duration of this effect or the changes that have taken place since the mentioned event.

examples.kr: 그 사고 이래로 제가 차를 못 타게 되었어요, 그래서 버스와 지하철로 이동을 하게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Geu sago iraero jega cha-reul mot tagae doe-eotseoyo, geuraeseo beoseuwa jihacheollo idongeul hage doe-eotseoyo.
examples.en: Since that accident, I have not been able to drive a car, so I have had to travel by bus and subway.

examples.kr: 봄이래 제가 꽃 알레르기에 고생을 많이 했어요, 그래서 약을 계속 먹고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Bom irae jegga kkoche allergy-e gosaeng-eul man-i haesseoyo, geuraeseo yak-eul gyesog meog-o iss-eoyo.
examples.en: Since spring, I have been suffering a lot from flower allergies, so I am constantly taking medicine.

examples.kr: 지난 회의 이래로 사무실 분위기가 계속 나빠지고 있어요, 많은 사람들이 불만을 표시하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jinan hwe-ui irae-ro samusil bun-wigiga gyesok napbajigo iss-eoyo, many people are expressing their displeasure.
examples.en: Since the last meeting, the office atmosphere has been continuously deteriorating, and many people are expressing their dissatisfaction.

examples.kr: 오랜만에 만난 친구가 결혼했다는 소식을 듣고 이래 못 마주쳤어요, 그래서 연락을 해야 할 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Oraenman-e mannahn chinguga gyeolhonhaessdaneun sosigeul deudgo irae mot majuchyeosseoyo, geuraeseo yeollageul haeya hal geos gat-ayo.
examples.en: I haven't run into my long-lost friend since I heard she got married, so I think I should contact her.

title: ~이야말로 [iyamallo] (Truly, really)
short_explanation: Used to emphasize that something or someone is the true or real example of something.
long_explanation: '~이야말로 [iyamallo]' is a grammar point in Korean that is used to emphasize a fact or situation by indicating that a particular description applies most appropriately or best to the noun that it is attached. It translates to 'truly' or 'really' in English and is used often when the speaker wants to assertively express the reality or truth of a situation, object or person.

examples.kr: 그 학생이야말로 모범적인 학생이에요, 그는 항상 열심히 공부하고 책임감이 강해요.
examples.romaji: Geu haksengiyamallo mobeomjeokin haksengieyo, geuneun hangsang yeolsimhi gongbuhago chaegimgami ganghaeyo.
examples.en: That student is truly an exemplary student, he always studies hard and has strong responsibility.

examples.kr: 지금 이 순간이야말로 우리가 기다렸던 기회입니다, 이번 기회를 놓치면 더 이상의 기회는 없을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Jigeum i sunganiyamallo uriga gidaryeotdeon gihoeyibnida, ibeon gihoereul nohcimyeon deo isangui gihoeuneun eobseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: This moment is truly the opportunity we have been waiting for, if we miss this opportunity, there will be no more.

examples.kr: 이 보컬이야말로 이 밴드의 핵심입니다, 그녀의 목소리 없이는 이 밴드가 상상조차 되지 않아요.
examples.romaji: I bokoriyamallo i baendeuyi haeksingibnida, geunyeoui moksori eobsineun i baendeuga sangsangjocha doeji anhayo.
examples.en: This vocalist is truly the core of the band, I can't even imagine the band without her voice.

examples.kr: 그 일이야말로 제 인생의 중요한 전환점이었습니다, 그 일로 인해 제 인생이 완전히 바뀌었어요.
examples.romaji: Geu iriyamallo je insaengui jungyohan jeonhwanjeomieossseubnida, geu ilro inhae je insaengi wanjeonhi bakkwieosseo.
examples.en: That incident was truly an important turning point in my life, my life changed completely because of it.

title: ~인 까닭에 [in kkadake] (Because, the reason why)
short_explanation: This is used to indicate 'because' or 'the reason why'. It gives the reason or cause for the action in the main clause.
long_explanation: '~인 까닭에 [in kkadake]' is a conjunction expression used in Korean to describe the reason or cause of something. It is used to provide an explanation or a rationale for a consequent action, event, or situation. It has a similar meaning to 'because' or 'the reason why' in English. It is generally used in more formal or literary contexts in contrast to colloquial counterparts such as '때문에 [ttaemune]' or '해서 [haeseo]'.

examples.kr: 부모님이 건강하신 까닭에 저는 항상 행복해요.
examples.romaji: Bumonim-i geonganghasin kkadake jeoneun hangsang haengbokhaeyo.
examples.en: I am always happy because my parents are healthy.

examples.kr: 날씨가 좋은 까닭에 저는 오늘 산책하러 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssi-ga jo-eun kkadake jeoneun oneul sancaekhaleo gasseoyo.
examples.en: I went for a walk today because the weather was nice.

examples.kr: 여행 준비를 철저히 한 까닭에 저는 여행 중에 불편함을 느끼지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Yeohaeng junbi-reul cheoljeohi han kkadake jeoneun yeohaeng jung-e bulbunham-eul neukkiji anhass-eoyo.
examples.en: I did not feel uncomfortable during the trip because I thoroughly prepared for the trip.

examples.kr: 문제를 꼼꼼히 살펴본 까닭에 방학 중에 공부할 때 하나도 다루지 않는 문제는 없어요.
examples.romaji: Munje-reul ggomggomhi salpyeobon kkadake banghak jung-e gongbuhal ttae hanado daruji anneun munjeneun eopseoyo.
examples.en: Because I carefully examined the problem, there are no problems I won't touch while studying during vacation.

title: ~인 즉 [in jeuk] (In other words)
short_explanation: Used to restate or clarify something in a different way; 'in other words', 'that is to say'.
long_explanation: '~인 즉 [in jeuk]' is a phrase used in Korean to restate or clarify something previously said with different words or in a more comprehensible way. It similar to the English expressions 'in other words', 'that is to say', or 'namely'. It helps offer further clarification or a different perspective to the initial statement.

examples.kr: 그는 특이한 사람입니다, 즉 그가 평범한 사람과는 다르게 행동하는 것을 의미합니다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun teukiin saramimnida, injeok geuga pyeongbeonhan saramgwaneun dareuge haengdonghaneun geoseul uimihabnida.
examples.en: He is an unusual person, in other words, it means he behaves differently from ordinary people.

examples.kr: 이번 시험은 어려웠습니다. 즉, 많은 학생들이 낮은 점수를 받았다는 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Ibeon siheomeun eoryeowosseumnida. Injeok, maneun haksaengdeuri najeun jeomsureul badatneun geosimnida.
examples.en: This exam was difficult. That is to say, many students received low scores.

examples.kr: 당신은 제 최고의 친구입니다, 즉 제가 가장 신뢰하는 사람입니다.
examples.romaji: Dangsineun je choegoui chinguimnida, injeok jegaga gajang sinroehaneun saramimnida.
examples.en: You are my best friend, in other words, you are the person I trust the most.

examples.kr: 지구가 따뜻해지고 있습니다, 즉 지구 온난화 현상이 일어나고 있는 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Jiguga ttatteutaejigo issseumnida, injeok jigu onnanhwa hyeonsangi ileonago issneun geosimnida.
examples.en: The Earth is getting warmer, in other words, global warming is happening.

title: ~처럼 하다 [cheoreom hada] (To act as if, pretend to)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used when expressing that someone is acting or behaving in a certain way, similar to 'as if', 'seem like' or 'pretend to' in English.
long_explanation: '~처럼 하다 [cheoreom hada]' is used when describing someone's behavior, attitude, or actions, which may not be their usual behavior but is done to create a similar effect to what is being described. This person might be pretending to be or behave like someone or something else or they might be imitating a certain way of actions or behavior.

examples.kr: 그는 사람들에게 기분 좋게 보이기 위해 기쁘다처럼 웃기만 했어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun saramdeurege gibun jotge boigi wihae gippeudacheoreom utgiman haesseoyo.
examples.en: He just laughed as if he was happy to make people feel good.

examples.kr: 제가 이해했다처럼 행동하려고 노력했지만 사실 많은 것을 이해하지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Jega ihaehaessdacheoreom haengdongharyeogo noryeokhaessjiman sasil manheun geoseul ihaehaji motaesseyo.
examples.en: I tried to act as if I understood, but in fact, I didn't understand many things.

examples.kr: 그녀는 자신의 문제를 모른다처럼 행동했어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun jasineui munjeleul moreundacheoreom haengdonghaesseoyo.
examples.en: She acted as if she didn't know about her own problem.

examples.kr: 그는 상황을 제어할 수 있다처럼 행동하려고 했지만, 사실은 그렇지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun sanghwangeul jeeohal su issdacheoreom haengdongharyeogo haessjiman, sasileun geureohji anhayo.
examples.en: He tried to act as if he could control the situation, but in reality, he couldn't.

title: ~커지다 [keojida]  (Become bigger, more important)
short_explanation: Used to express the increase in size, importance, urgency, or significance of something or someone.
long_explanation: The verb '커지다 [keojida]' is used to indicate something becoming bigger, more significant, or more important. This verb can be used in different contexts to express changes in physical size, importance, or relevance of a subject or object. Its usage is generally associated with positive growth or expansion, including emotional, physical, and abstract growth, making it versatile in various contexts.

examples.kr: 나는 자라면서 내 꿈이 더 크고 중요해져서 스스로 변경하게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun jarimyeonseo nae kkumi deo keogo jungyohaejyeoseo seuseuro byeonghage doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: As I grew up, my dreams became bigger and more important, causing me to change on my own.

examples.kr: 그 회사는 확장하면서 그의 역할이 점점 중요하게 커졌어요.
examples.romaji: Geu hwesaneun hwangjanghamyeonseo geuui yeog hari jeomjeom jungyohage keojyeosseoyo.
examples.en: As the company expanded, his role became increasingly more important.

examples.kr: 저희 집 가족의 사랑은 저희가 함께 시간을 보내며 점점 커져요.
examples.romaji: Jeohui jib gajog-ui sarangeun jeohui-ga hamkke siganeul bonaemyeo jeomjeom keojyeoyo.
examples.en: Our family's love grows bigger as we spend time together.

examples.kr: 이슈가 계속되면서 그 문제의 중요성은 커져만 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Isugagi gyesokdoemyeonseo geu munjeui jungyoseong-eun keojyeoman gass-eoyo.
examples.en: As the issue continued, the importance of that problem only grew.

title: ~키로 하다 [kiro hada] (Intend to, plan to)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to denote the speaker's intention or resolution to do something.
long_explanation: The grammar form '~키로 하다 [kiro hada]' is used in Korean when expressing an intention, decision, or plan to do something in the future. It conveys a sense of resolution and a conscious decision made by the speaker. This is generally translated as 'intend to' or 'plan to' in English.
formation: Verb in dictionary form + 키로 하다

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 완벽하게 배울 키로 했습니다 그래서 매일 많은 연습을 하고 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeoreul wanbyeokhage baeul kiro haetsseumnida geuraeseo maeil maneun yeonseubeul hago issseumnida.
examples.en: I have decided to learn Korean perfectly, so I am practising a lot every day.

examples.kr: 우리는 내년에 결혼할 키로 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Uri-neun naenyeone gyeolhonhal ki-ro haetsseumnida.
examples.en: We have decided to get married next year.

examples.kr: 다이어트를 시작할 키로 했어요 그래서 매일 운동하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Daieteureul sijakhal kiro himself geuraeseo maeil undonghago isseoyo.
examples.en: I have decided to start dieting, so I am exercising every day.

examples.kr: 사장님은 회사를 확장할 키로 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Sajangnimeun hoesareul hwakjanghal kiro haetsseumnida.
examples.en: The boss has decided to expand the company.

title: ~하기에는 [hagineun] (Considering)
short_explanation: Used to express 'considering' or 'given that'.
long_explanation: '~하기에는 [hagineun]' is a grammar point in Korean that's used when considering or contemplating about certain information before making statements, decisions, or judgements. It is often connected to the verb stem to denote that considering a certain aspect, the upcoming statement is then followed or interpreted.

examples.kr: 오늘은 비가 와서 축구를 하기에는 좀 어렵겠어요.
examples.romaji: Oneureun biga wasseo chukgureul hagineun jom eoryeobgesseoyo.
examples.en: Considering that it's raining today, it might be a bit difficult to play soccer.

examples.kr: 저는 돈이 너무 없어서 여행을 가기에는 불가능해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun doni neomu eopsseo yeohaengeul gagineun bulganeunghaeyo.
examples.en: Considering that I don't have much money, it's impossible for me to travel.

examples.kr: 이 프로젝트를 완성하기에는 시간이 부족해요.
examples.romaji: I peurojekteu reul wanseonghagineun sigani bujokhaeyo.
examples.en: Considering the time, it's not enough to complete this project.

examples.kr: 이 영화를 보기에는 너무 무서워서 안될 거 같아요.
examples.romaji: I yeonghwaleul bogineun neomu museowoseo andoel geo gatayo.
examples.en: Considering it's too scary, I don't think I can watch this movie.

title: ~하기는 하다 [hagineun hada] (Do it somehow)
short_explanation: Used to express the idea that someone does something but not proficiently or adequately
long_explanation: The expression '~하기는 하다 [hagineun hada]' is used in Korean to convey the nuance that someone does something but not quite efficiently, proficiently, or adequately. Therefore, it is often used when implying that even though someone technically does something, it doesn't meet the standard or expectation or isn't done well enough.

examples.kr: 제가 요리를 하기는 하는데, 그렇게 맛있게는 안 나와요.
examples.romaji: Jega yorireul hagineun haneunde, geureoke masitge-neun an nawayo.
examples.en: I do cook, but it doesn't turn out that delicious.

examples.kr: 우리 회사에는 일을 하기는 하는데, 잘 하는 사람이 별로 없어요.
examples.romaji: Uri hwesaeneun ireul hagineun haneunde, jal haneun sarami byeollo eopseoyo.
examples.en: In our company, people do work but there aren't many who do it well.

examples.kr: 그는 학교를 다니기는 하는데, 실제로는 못 하는 과목이 많아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun hakgyoreul danigineun haneunde, siljero-neun mot haneun gwamogi manh-ayo.
examples.en: He does attend school, but in reality, there are many subjects he can't do.

examples.kr: 나는 영어를 말하기는 하는데, 자연스럽게 말하진 못해요.
examples.romaji: Naneun yeong-eoreul malhagineun haneunde, jayeon-seureopge malhajin moth-ayo.
examples.en: I do speak English, but I can't speak it fluently.

title: ~하기야 [hagiya] (Indeed, truly)
short_explanation: Used to emphasize or affirm; 'indeed', 'truly', 'to be sure'.
long_explanation: '~하기야 [hagiya]' is a grammatical form used in Korean to stress or provide a clear-cut confirmation of the current topic of discussion. It conveys a sense of affirmation, akin to 'indeed' or 'truly' in English. It is often used to stress the truth of a statement or to affirm one's own viewpoint in a conversation.

examples.kr: 요즘 친구들에게 공부가 어렵다고 하기야 힘들어요, 그러니까 매일 night study가 필요해요.
examples.romaji: Yojeum chingudeurege gongbuga eoryeodago hagiya himdeureoyo, geureonikka maeil night studyga piryohaeyo.
examples.en: Indeed, studying is difficult for my friends these days, so night study is necessary every day.

examples.kr: 이제 코로나19 바이러스가 퍼져서 여행하러 나가기 힘들다 하기야 사실이에요, 그래서 집에서만 시간을 보내고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Ije korona19 baireoseuga peojyeoseo yeohaenghareo nagagi himdeulda hagiya sasirieyo, geuraeseo jibeseoman siganeul bonaego isseoyo.
examples.en: Indeed it is true that due to Covid-19, it is difficult to go out for travel, so I am spending time at home only.

examples.kr: 학교에 관한 것이 아니라면 그걸 하기야 원합니다, 학교에 있을 때보다 훨씬 더 흥미있고 즐거워요.
examples.romaji: Hakgyoe gwanhan geosi aniramyeon geugeol hagiya wonhamnida, hakgyoe isseul ttaeboda hwolssin deo hungmiitgo jeulgeowoyo.
examples.en: Indeed, I would like to do it if it is not about school, it's much more interesting and enjoyable than when I'm at school.

examples.kr: 맛있는 음식을 만드는 것은 어렵다고 하기야 그래요, 그러나 매일 노력하면 점차 능력이 향상될 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Masinneun eumsigeul mandeuneun geoseun eoryeodago hagiya geuraeyo, geureona maeil noryeokhamyeon jeomcha neungryeogi hyangsangdoel geosibnida.
examples.en: Indeed, making delicious food is difficult, but if you try every day, your ability will gradually improve.

title: ~하기만 하면 [hakiman hamyeon] (As soon as)
short_explanation: Used to express 'as soon as' or 'whenever'.
long_explanation: '~하기만 하면 [hakiman hamyeon]' is a frequently used grammar form in Korean, which means 'as soon as' or 'whenever'. When this structure is used, it means that as soon as a particular action (identified by a verb for which '하기' is attached) happens or whenever it happens, another event or action (identified by a verb which follows the '만 하면' part) happens immediately or consequently. It’s used to refer to actions that follow immediately after another.

examples.kr: 나는 매일 아침 일어나기만 하면 운동을 합니다.
examples.romaji: Naneun maeil achim ileonagiman hamyeon undongeul habnida.
examples.en: I exercise as soon as I wake up every morning.

examples.kr: 그녀가 집에 도착하기만 하면 바로 저녁을 만들어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga jibe dochakhagiman hamyeon baro jeonyeogeul mandeureoyo.
examples.en: As soon as she arrives home, she starts to make dinner.

examples.kr: 수업이 끝나기만 하면 학생들이 즉시 학교를 떠납니다.
examples.romaji: Sueobi ggeutnagiman hamyeon haksaengdeuli jeugshi hakgyoreul tteonabnida.
examples.en: The students leave school immediately as soon as the class ends.

examples.kr: 그가 긴장하기만 하면 어깨가 떨립니다.
examples.romaji: Geuga ginjanghagiman hamyeon eokkaega tteollibnida.
examples.en: His shoulders shake whenever he gets nervous.

title: ~하면서도 [hamyeonseodo] (While, although)
short_explanation: Used to express a contradictory situation or event occurring at the same time; 'while', 'although'.
long_explanation: '~하면서도 [hamyeonseodo]' is a conjunction used in Korean to indicate two actions or states happening simultaneously, with an aspect of contradiction or conflicting elements. It's like saying 'although' or 'even when' in English, and implies that despite the first action, the second one still occurs. It can be used to show inconsistency between what is expected and what really happens.

examples.kr: 그녀는 회사에서 바쁘게 일하면서도 항상 일찍 집에 가서 아이들과 식사를 함께해요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun hoesaeseo bappeuge ilhamyeonseodo hangsang iljjik jibe gaseo aideulgwa siksa reul hamkkehaeyo.
examples.en: Even as she works hard at the company, she always goes home early to have meals with her children.

examples.kr: 저는 공부에 집중하면서도 친구들과 소통하는 데에는 어려움이 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun gongbue jipjunghamyeonseodo chingudeulgwa sotonghaneun deeneun eoryeoumi isseoyo.
examples.en: While focusing on studies, I find it difficult to communicate with friends.

examples.kr: 그는 연인과 행복하게 지내면서도, 그녀가 항상 곁에 없을 때를 두려워해요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun yeoningwa haengbokhage jjinaemyeonseodo, geunyeoga hangsang gyeote eobseul ttaereul duryeowohaeyo.
examples.en: Even as he spends happy times with his lover, he fears the times when she is not by his side.

examples.kr: 어머니는 항상 건강에 신경을 쓰면서도, 자신의 건강은 항상 무시하곤 해요.
examples.romaji: Eomeonineun hangsang geongange singyeongeul sseumyeonseodo, jasinui geongangeun hangsang musihagon haeyo.
examples.en: While mom always takes care of our health, she tends to ignore her own health.

title: ~하면 할수록 [hamyeon halsurok] (The more... the more)
short_explanation: Used to express a correlation between two actions or situations; 'the more... the more'
long_explanation: The '~하면 할수록 [hamyeon halsurok]' grammar point is used to express a correlation between two things. The first clause shows what is increasing or decreasing, while the second clause shows the result. This pattern is used to emphasize that as one event or situation increases or decreases, a related event or situation also increases or decreases, much like the English expression 'the more... the more'.

examples.kr: 이것을 연습하면 연습할수록 더 잘해져서, 계속 연습하면 제가 마스터 할 수 있을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Igeoseul yeonseubhamyeon yeonseubhalsurok deo jalhaejeoseo, gyesok yeonseubhamyeon jega maseuteo hal su isseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: The more I practice this, the better I get, so if I keep practicing, I could master it.

examples.kr: 날씨가 추워지면 추워질수록 더 많은 사람들이 옷가게에 들렀어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga chuwojimyeon chuwojilsurok deo manheun saramdeuli otgagee deulleosseoyo.
examples.en: The colder the weather gets, the more people stop by the clothing store.

examples.kr: 나는 한국어를 공부하면 공부할수록 그 언어에 대해 더 알고 싶어져요.
examples.romaji: Naneun hangugeoreul gongbuhalsurok gongbuhalsurok geu eoneoe daehae deo algo sipheojyeoyo.
examples.en: The more I study Korean, the more I want to know about the language.

examples.kr: 이 도시에 살면 살수록 더 많은 볼거리와 할 것들이 있는 걸 알게 됐어요.
examples.romaji: I dosiye salsurok salsurok deo manheun bolgeoriwa hal geosdeuli issneun geol alge dwaesseoyo.
examples.en: The longer I live in this city, the more I find there is to see and do.

title: ~하자마자 [hajamaja] (As soon as)
short_explanation: Used to express 'as soon as' or 'right after' something has happened.
long_explanation: '~하자마자 [hajamaja]' is a conjugation used in Korean to indicate an action that is followed immediately by another one, implying no gap in between. Essentially, it means 'as soon as' or 'right after'. It creates a link between two actions where the second action happens directly after the first

examples.kr: 학교에 도착하자마자 그는 수업에 바로 들어갔습니다.
examples.romaji: Hakgyoe dochakhajamaja geuneun sueobe baro deuleogassseubnida.
examples.en: As soon as he arrived at school, he went straight to class.

examples.kr: 저는 공항에 도착하자마자 택시를 불렀어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun gonghang-e dochakhajamaja taeksileul bulleoss-eoyo.
examples.en: As soon as I arrived at the airport, I called a taxi.

examples.kr: 그녀는 일어나자마자 커피를 만들었습니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun ileonajamaja keopireul mandeuleossseubnida.
examples.en: As soon as she woke up, she made coffee.

examples.kr: 회사에서 퇴근하자마자 집에 바로 가서 쉬었어요.
examples.romaji: Hoesaeseo toeguenhajamaja jibe baro gaseo swieosseoyo.
examples.en: As soon as I got off work from the company, I went straight home and rested.

title: ~하여 그런지 [hayeo geureonji] (Perhaps because)
short_explanation: Used to express a supposition, assumption, or speculation; 'perhaps because', 'maybe due to'.
long_explanation: '~하여 그런지 [hayeo geureonji]' is commonly used in Korean grammar to indicate a speculative cause and effect relationship or a supposition. It is generally translated into English as 'perhaps because' or 'maybe due to'. This grammar construction is typically used when the speaker doesn't have full certainty about the relationship between two things but is speculating based on observable evidence or logical assumption.

examples.kr: 오늘은 날씨가 좋아서 그런지 사람들이 많이 활동하는 것을 볼 수 있었습니다.
examples.romaji: Oneureun nalssiga johaseo geureonji saramdeuri mani hwaldonghaneun geoseul bol su isseossseubnida.
examples.en: Perhaps because the weather is nice today, I could see a lot of people being active.

examples.kr: 그녀는 어제 다치고 나서 그런지 오늘은 엄청 조심스럽게 걸어갔습니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun eoje dachigo naseo geureonji oneureun eomcheong josimseureopge georeogassseubnida.
examples.en: Maybe because she got hurt yesterday, she walked very carefully today.

examples.kr: 어제 짜장면을 너무 많이 먹었나 봐요, 오늘은 배가 아파서 그런지 컨디션이 좋지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Eoje jjajangmyeoneul neomu mani meogeossnabwayo, oneureun baega apaseo geureonji keondisyeoni joji anhayo.
examples.en: Perhaps because I ate too much black bean noodles yesterday, I don't feel well today, maybe due to a stomachache.

examples.kr: 나는 꿈에서 그녀를 만났으니까 그런지 오늘은 그녀가 계속 생각나요.
examples.romaji: Naneun kkumeseo geunyeoreul mannasseunikka geureonji oneureun geunyeoga gyesok saenggaknayo.
examples.en: Maybe because I met her in my dream, I keep thinking about her today.

title: ~하여서는 안 되다 [hayeoseoneun an dweda] (Must not)
short_explanation: Used to express prohibition or strong advice against doing something, which can be translated as 'must not' or 'should not'.
long_explanation: '~하여서는 안 되다 [hayeoseoneun an dweda]' is a grammar form used to indicate something that should not or must not occur. It is often used when giving strong advice or setting prohibitions. It highlights the negative consequences that may occur if the action is performed.
formation: Verb Stem + 아/어/여 + 하여서는 안 되다

examples.kr: 학생들이라고 해서 수업에 늦게 오는 것은 절대로 하여서는 안 되다.
examples.romaji: Haksaengdeulirago haeseo sueobe neuje omneun geoseun jeoldaero hayeoseoneun an dweda.
examples.en: Just because they are students, they absolutely must not come to class late.

examples.kr: 의사로서 환자에 대한 사항을 외부에 누설하는 것을 하여서는 안 되다.
examples.romaji: Uisaroseo hwanjae daehan sahangeul oebue nuseorhaneun geoseul hayeoseoneun an dweda.
examples.en: As a doctor, you must not leak patient information to the outside.

examples.kr: 내일 시험 때문에 밤 새운다고 하여서는 안 되다, 건강이 먼저이다.
examples.romaji: Naeil siheom ttaemune bam saeundago hayeoseoneun an dweda, geongangi meonjeo-ida.
examples.en: You must not stay up all night because of tomorrow's exam, health comes first.

examples.kr: 다른 사람에게 피해를 주는 행동을 하여서는 안 되다.
examples.romaji: Dareun saram-ege pihaereul juneun haengdong-eul hayeoseoneun an dweda.
examples.en: You must not engage in actions that harm others.

title: ~한테는 [hanteneun] (To, for someone)
short_explanation: Used to indicate the target or recipient of an action, similar to 'to' or 'for' in English.
long_explanation: '~한테는 [hanteneun]' is a grammar construction in Korean often used when the speaker wants to indicate the recipient or target of an action, making it similar to 'to' or 'for' in English. It can also be used to specify someone (usually the person spoken to or spoken about) in contrast to others.

examples.kr: 제 언니한테는 선물을 사려고 여기에 와서 쇼핑을 합니다, 제 친구한테는 이메일로 메시지를 보낼 예정입니다.
examples.romaji: Je eonni-hanteneun seon-mul-eul sa-ryeogo yeogi-e wa-seo sho-ping-eul habnida, je chingu-hanteneun i-mei-ro me-si-ji-reul bonael yejeong-ibnida.
examples.en: I came here to shop for a gift for my older sister, and I plan to send a message to my friend by email.

examples.kr: 아버지한테는 이 사실을 아직 알리지 않았어요, 언니에게만 이야기했어요.
examples.romaji: Abeoji-hanteneun i sasil-eul ajik alliji anh-ass-eoyo, eonni-ege-man iyagihaess-eoyo.
examples.en: I have not yet told my father about this, I only spoke to my older sister.

examples.kr: 아이들한테는 단순한 언어로 설명해야 합니다, 너무 복잡하면 이해할 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Aideul-hanteneun dansunhan eon-eo-ro seolmyeonghaeya habnida, neomu bokjabhamyeon ihaehal su eobs-eoyo.
examples.en: You need to explain in simple language to children, if it's too complex, they won't understand.

examples.kr: 그는 엄마한테는 항상 친절하고, 아빠한테는 무례해요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun eommahanteneun hangsang chinjeolhago, abbahanteneun muryehaeyo.
examples.en: He is always kind to his mom, but rude to his dad.

title: ~할 만하다 [hal manhada] (Worth doing)
short_explanation: Used to express the worthiness of doing something.
long_explanation: '~할 만하다 [hal manhada]' is a Korean grammar point used to indicate that something is worth the effort, time, or cost invested into it. It can be translated as 'worth doing' or 'worth it' in English. The speaker uses it to express a subjective assessment of worthiness or a positive value judgment.

examples.kr: 요리 공부를 계속하는 게 어렵지만, 맛있는 음식을 자주 먹을 수 있게 되니까 할 만해요.
examples.romaji: Yori gongbureul gyesokhaneun ge eoryeopjiman, masissneun eumsigeul jaju meogeul su issge doenikka hal manhaeyo.
examples.en: Continuing to study cooking is difficult, but it's worth it because it allows me to eat delicious food often.

examples.kr: 이 작품은 비싸기는 하지만, 아름다운 디자인과 고품질로 볼 때, 사는 것이 할 만해요.
examples.romaji: I jagpumeun bissagineun hajiman, areumdawun dijain-gwa gopumjillo bol ttae, saneun geosi hal manhaeyo.
examples.en: This piece is expensive, but considering its beautiful design and high quality, it's worth buying.

examples.kr: 긴 시간을 기다리는 것은 힘들지만, 그 결과가 좋으면 할 만합니다.
examples.romaji: Gin siganeul gidarineun geoseun himdeuljiman, geu gyeolgwa ga joheumyeon hal manhamnida.
examples.en: Waiting for a long time is tough, but if the result is good, it's worth it.

examples.kr: 이 영화는 별로 재미있지 않기 때문에, 보는 것이 할 만하지 않아요.
examples.romaji: I yeonghwaneun byeollo jaemiissji anhgi ttaemune, boneun geosi hal manhji anhayo.
examples.en: This movie is not very interesting, so it's not worth watching.

title: ~할 수밖에 없다 [hal subakke eopda] (Have no choice but to)
short_explanation: Used to express that there is no other option but to do what is mentioned.
long_explanation: '~할 수밖에 없다 [hal subakke eopda]' is a common Korean grammar structure used to imply that there is no other option available other than to do the action mentioned, it basically means 'have no choice but to'. This phrase is used when faced with a situation where you have no other alternative action.

examples.kr: 비가 오니까 우산을 가지고 갈 수밖에 없어요.
examples.romaji: Biga onigga usaneul gajigo gal subakke eopseoyo.
examples.en: Since it's raining, I have no choice but to bring an umbrella.

examples.kr: 시험이 있기 때문에 공부를 계속 해야 할 수밖에 없어요.
examples.romaji: Siheomi itgi ddemune gongbureul gyesok haeya hal subakke eopseoyo.
examples.en: Because there is an exam, I have no choice but to keep studying.

examples.kr: 그녀가 그렇게 말했으니까, 나는 그녀를 신뢰할 수밖에 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga geureoke malhaessunikka, naneun geunyeoreul sinroehal subakke eopseosseoyo.
examples.en: Since she said so, I had no choice but to trust her.

examples.kr: 지금 돈이 없어서 이렇게 저렴한 물건밖에 살 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Jigeum doni eopseoseo ireoke jeoryeomhan mulgeonbakke sal subakke eopseoyo.
examples.en: I have no money now, so I have no choice but to buy such cheap items.

title: ~해 갈수록 [hae galsurok] (Increasingly, as time goes on)
short_explanation: This expression is used to describe a situation where a certain state, condition, or action progressively or increasingly continues or becomes serious.
long_explanation: The '~해 갈수록 [hae galsurok]' grammatical expression is used in Korean to indicate that as time goes on, a particular state or condition is progressively intensifying or worsening. The phrase is compatible with both verbs and adjectives. It provides an expression of progression that is increasingly continuous or becoming more serious or intense. It is equivalent to the English phrases ‘increasingly,’ ‘the more...the more,’ or 'as time goes on.'

examples.kr: 날씨가 춥게 갈수록 감기 걸리는 사람이 많아지는 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga chupge galsurok gamgi geollineun sarami manhajineun geot gatayo.
examples.en: The colder the weather gets, the more people seem to catch a cold.

examples.kr: 그녀는 알게 갈수록 더 매력적인 사람이에요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeo-neun alge galsurok deo maeryeokjeogin saram-ieyo.
examples.en: The more I get to know her, the more attractive she becomes.

examples.kr: 책을 읽을수록 나의 사고력이 향상되는 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Chaeg-eul ilgeulsurok na-ui sagolig-i hyangsangdoeneun geot gat-ayo.
examples.en: The more I read, the more I feel that my thinking ability improves.

examples.kr: 저는 집에 있을수록 외로워져요, 그래서 외출을 좋아해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun jibe isseulsurok werowojyeoyo, geuraeseo oechul-eul joh-ayo.
examples.en: The more I stay at home, the lonelier I become, so I like going out.

title: ~해 보아야 [hae boaya] (Should try and see)
short_explanation: Used to suggest that somebody should try something out to know or understand it.
long_explanation: '~해 보아야 [hae boaya]' is a Korean grammar structure used when you want to suggest that one should try something to really know or understand it. It is often used when you want to express an open-minded perspective towards trying new experiences or ideas. In English, a similar phrase could be 'should try and see'.

examples.kr: 음식이 신선한지 아는 방법은 먹어 보아야 해요.
examples.romaji: Eumsik-i sinseonhanji aneun bangbeob-eun meog-eo boaya haeyo.
examples.en: The way to know if the food is fresh is to try and eat it.

examples.kr: 이 옷이 어떤지 아는 방법은 입어 보아야 해요.
examples.romaji: I ot-i eotteonji aneun bangbeob-eun ib-eo boaya haeyo.
examples.en: The way to know how these clothes are is to try them on.

examples.kr: 이 책이 재미있는지 아는 방법은 읽어 보아야 해요.
examples.romaji: I chaeg-i jaemiissneunji aneun bangbeob-eun ilg-eo boaya haeyo.
examples.en: The way to know if this book is interesting is to try and read it.

examples.kr: 이 스포츠가 얼마나 재미있는지 아는 방법은 직접 해 보아야 해요.
examples.romaji: I seupocheu-ga eolmana jaemiissneunji aneun bangbeob-eun jikjeop hae boaya haeyo.
examples.en: The way to know how fun this sport is, is by trying it out.

title: ~해오다 [haeoda] (Continue doing something until now)
short_explanation: Used to express an ongoing action from the past up to the present moment.
long_explanation: '해오다 [haeoda]' is used to denote an action that started in the past and is continuing until now. It literally means 'have been doing'. This grammar point is often used to express a continuous habit, ongoing action, or a series of actions that have taken place over an extended period of time.

examples.kr: 나는 어렸을 때부터 피아노를 치고 있어요 제 취미가 되어 오고 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Naneun eoryeosseul ttaebuteo pianoreul chigo isseoyo je chwimiga doeeo ogo issseubnida.
examples.en: I have been playing the piano since I was young, it has become my hobby.

examples.kr: 우리는 그 사업을 시작한 지 5년 동안 일해오고 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Urineun geu saeobeul sijakhan ji 5nyeon dongan ilhaeoogo issseumnida.
examples.en: We have been working on that business for five years since we started.

examples.kr: 세계 여행을 꿈꾸며 돈을 아껴오고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Segye yeohaengeul kkumkkumyeo doneul akkyeooigo isseoyo.
examples.en: I have been saving money dreaming of a world tour.

examples.kr: 우리는 친구가 왔을 때부터 함께 이야기해오고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun chinguga wasseul ttaebuteo hamkke iyagihaeoogo isseoyo.
examples.en: We have been telling stories together since our friend came.

title: ~했건만 [haetgeonman] (But, however)
short_explanation: Used to express contrast or contradiction; 'but', 'however'.
long_explanation: The '~했건만 [haetgeonman]' is a complex grammatical form used in Korean to express a contrasting situation or contradiction. It can roughly be translated to 'but', 'nevertheless', or 'however' in English, and is generally used when the speaker wants to present a fact or situation that contradicts to the previous statement. It signifies that despite what was previously stated, a contrasting or contradictory circumstance arises.

examples.kr: 저는 많이 노력했건만, 시험에 떨어졌습니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun mani noryeokhaetgeonman, siheome ddeoleojyeossseubnida.
examples.en: I made a lot of efforts, but I failed the exam.

examples.kr: 친구는 어제 왔건만, 오늘은 못 왔습니다.
examples.romaji: Chinguneun eojewatgeonman, oneureun mot watseubnida.
examples.en: My friend came yesterday but could not make it today.

examples.kr: 음식은 맛있었건만, 가격이 너무 비쌌습니다.
examples.romaji: Eumsikeun masisseotgeonman, gagyeogi neomu bissassseubnida.
examples.en: The food was delicious but it was too expensive.

examples.kr: 그녀는 예쁘다고 했건만, 저는 그렇게 생각하지 않았습니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun yeppeudago haetgeonman, jeoneun geureohge saenggakaji anhatsseubnida.
examples.en: She said she was pretty, but I didn't think so.

title: ~했기 때문에 [haetgi ttaemune] (Because)
short_explanation: Used to express reason or cause, equivalent to 'Because' in English.
long_explanation: '~했기 때문에 [haetgi ttaemune]' is a grammar used to express reason or cause in Korean. It translates to 'Because' in English. It is a retrospective expression, which means it's referring back to a situation or actions that have taken place in the past for giving a reason for present actions or situations.
formation: Action Verb in Past Tense + 했기 때문에

examples.kr: 어제 늦게 잤기 때문에 오늘 아침에 일어나기 힘들었어요.
examples.romaji: Eoje neutge jatgi ttaemune oneul achime ileonagi himdeureosseoyo.
examples.en: Because I went to bed late last night, it was hard for me to wake up this morning.

examples.kr: 미세먼지가 많이 높아서 창문을 열지 않았기 때문에 방이 더워졌어요.
examples.romaji: Mise meonjiga mani nopaseo changmuneul yeolji anhatgi ttaemune bangi deowojyeosseoyo.
examples.en: Because I didn't open the window as the fine dust level was high, the room got hot.

examples.kr: 많은 공부를 했기 때문에 시험에서 좋은 점수를 받았어요.
examples.romaji: Manneun gongbureul haetgi ttaemune siheomeseo joheun jeomsureul badasseoyo.
examples.en: Because I studied a lot, I got a good score on the exam.

examples.kr: 비가 왔기 때문에 운동화가 젖었어요.
examples.romaji: Biga watgi ttaemune undonghwaga jeojeosseoyo.
examples.en: Because it rained, my sneakers got wet.

title: ~했기에 [haetgie] (Because)
short_explanation: Used to indicate the reason or cause; 'because' or 'since'.
long_explanation: `~했기에 [haetgie]` is a conjunction used in Korean to connect two sentences where the first sentence is the cause or reason for the second sentence. It lays emphasis on the connection between the two sentences, pointing out that the first happened or exists because of the second. It is equivalent to 'because' or 'since' in English.

examples.kr: 그녀는 학문을 아주 좋아했기에, 대학에서 교수가 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun hakmuneul aju joahaetgie, daehageseo gyosuga doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: She became a professor at the university because she really loved academics.

examples.kr: 저는 갈비를 많이 먹었기에, 지금 배가 너무 불러요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun galbireul manhi meogeotgie, jigeum baega neomu bulleoyo.
examples.en: I ate a lot of ribs, so now I am very full.

examples.kr: 오늘 일찍 일어났기에, 출근할 시간에 늦지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul iljjik ileonatgie, chulgeunhal sigane neujji anhasseoyo.
examples.en: I woke up early today, so I was not late for work.

examples.kr: 그는 개인적인 문제 때문에 스트레스를 받았기에, 단체 활동에 참여하지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun gaeinjeogin munje ttaemune seuteureseureul badatgie, danche hwaldonge chamyeohaji anhasseoyo.
examples.en: He did not participate in the group activity because he was stressed due to personal issues.

title: ~했더니 [haetdeoni] (And then)
short_explanation: Used to express the progression of actions or events in the form of 'and then'; the consequential relationship between two situations.
long_explanation: The '~했더니 [haetdeoni]' expression is used in the Korean language to indicate a cause and effect relationship between two situations or actions, often in a chronological order. The first clause is something the speaker did or noticed, and the second clause is the unexpected or surprising result or consequence. It can be translated as 'and then' or 'so' in English.

examples.kr: 그녀에게 전화했더니 그녀는 바빠서 전화를 받을 수 없다고 했어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoege jeonhwahaetdeoni geunyeoneun bappaseo jeonhwareul badeul su eopsdago haesseoyo.
examples.en: I called her and then she said she was too busy to answer the call.

examples.kr: 저는 버스에서 내렸더니 지갑을 잃어버렸다는 것을 깨달았어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun beoseueseo naeryeotdeoni jigabeul ilheobeoryeotdaneun geoseul ggaedalatseoyo.
examples.en: I got off the bus and then realized that I had lost my wallet.

examples.kr: 나는 책을 읽었더니 창문 밖에 비가 오고 있는 것을 봤어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun chaegilgeosseotdeoni changmun bakke biga ogo issneun geoseul bwasseoyo.
examples.en: I was reading a book and then I saw it was raining outside the window.

examples.kr: 약을 먹었더니 기분이 좋아졌어요.
examples.romaji: Yageul meogeossdeoni gibuni johajyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I took a pill and then I felt better.

title: ~했어야 했다 [haesseoya haetda] (Had to)
short_explanation: This expression is used to indicate that something 'had to' be done in the past.
long_explanation: '~했어야 했다 [haesseoya haetda]' is a Korean grammar structure that expresses something that 'had to' happen or 'should have' been done in the past, but it's unclear whether it was actually done or not. This structure is usually used to express regret, missed opportunities, or lamenting about what one did not do but should have done in the past.

examples.kr: 어제 그 일을 끝냈어야 했는데, 시간이 부족해서 끝내지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Eoje geu ileul kkeutnesseoya haetneunde, sigani bujokhaeseo kkeutnaeji motaesseoyo.
examples.en: I should have finished that work yesterday, but I couldn't because I didn't have enough time.

examples.kr: 학원에 가서 공부했어야 했는데, 게임을 하느라고 갈 수 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Hagwone gaseo gongbuhaesseoya haetneunde, geimeul haneurago gal su eopseosseoyo.
examples.en: I should have gone to the academy and studied, but I couldn't because I was playing games.

examples.kr: 커피 대신 물을 마셨어야 했는데, 카페인이 많아서 잠이 안 왔어요.
examples.romaji: Keopi daesin mureul masyeosseoya haetneunde, kapeini manhaseo jami an wasseoyo.
examples.en: I should have drunk water instead of coffee, but I couldn't sleep because there was a lot of caffeine.

examples.kr: 전화를 받았어야 했는데, 전화기를 못 봐서 받지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeonhwaleul badesseoya haetneunde, jeonhwagireul mot bwaseo badji motaesseoyo.
examples.en: I should have answered the phone, but I didn't because I couldn't see the phone.

title: ~혹은 [hogeun] (Or)
short_explanation: Used to express options or alternatives; 'or'.
long_explanation: '~혹은 [hogeun]' is a conjunction used in Korean to present two or more alternatives or choices without prioritizing or focusing on any particular one, akin to 'or' in English. It is used to give options, and is often positioned between the options that are being offered.

examples.kr: 당신은 커피 혹은 차를 원하세요?
examples.romaji: Dangsin-eun keopi hogeun chaleul wonhaseyo?
examples.en: Would you like coffee or tea?

examples.kr: 이 문제를 해결하기 위해서는 시간 혹은 노력이 필요하겠어요.
examples.romaji: I munjeleul haegyeolhagi wihaeseoneun sigan hogeun noryeogi pilyohagesseoyo.
examples.en: Time or effort is needed to solve this problem.

examples.kr: 그는 강아지 혹은 고양이를 키우고 싶어 했어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun gangaji hogeun goyangireul kiugo sip-eo haess-eoyo.
examples.en: He wanted to raise a puppy or a kitten.

examples.kr: 여름 휴가를 보내기 위해 바닷가 혹은 산에서 휴가를 보낼 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Yeoleum hyugaleul bonae-gi wihae badasga hogeun san-eseo hyugaleul bonael su iss-eoyo.
examples.en: You can spend your summer vacation at the beach or in the mountains.

title: 후에야 [hueya] (Only after)
short_explanation: Used to indicate something happened or was realized only after a certain event or time.
long_explanation: '후에야 [hueya]' is a compound word in Korean composed of '후에', which means 'after', and '야', which means 'only'. It is used when an action or realization takes place only after a certain event or period of time has passed, adding emphasis to the delay or the subsequent impact of that event. The event or time mentioned before '후에야' is a necessary precondition for the action or realization that comes afterwards.

examples.kr: 그녀가 날 떠나고 후에야 난 그녀를 얼마나 사랑하는지 알았어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga nal tteonago hueya nan geunyeoreul eolmana saranghaneunji alatseoyo.
examples.en: Only after she left me did I realize how much I loved her.

examples.kr: 시험을 보고 후에야 이 문제의 정답이 무엇인지 기억이 났어요.
examples.romaji: Siheomeul bogo hueya i munjeui jeongdabi mueosinji gieogi nasseoyo.
examples.en: Only after taking the test, I remembered what the correct answer to this question was.

examples.kr: 나는 대학을 졸업하고 후에야 진짜로 배워야 할 것이 무엇인지 이해했어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun daehageul joreophago hueya jinjjaro baewoya hal geosi mueosinji ihaehaetseoyo.
examples.en: Only after I graduated from university did I understand what I really should learn.

examples.kr: 일을 시작하고 후에야 할 일이 얼마나 많은지 알게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Ileul sijakhago hueya hal ili eolmana manheunji alge doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: Only after starting to work did I realize how much work there was to do.

title: ~흔히 [heunhi] (Commonly, often)
short_explanation: Used to indicate that an event or situation happens frequently or is commonly known.
long_explanation: '~흔히 [heunhi]' is an adverb used in Korean to demonstrate that something happens frequently, is a common occurrence, or is typically known. It is very similar to English expressions like 'often', 'commonly', 'usually' or 'typically'. It is often used in either objective descriptions to describe common events or facts, or in subjective interpretations to highlight personal observations.

examples.kr: 흔히 사람들은 건강한 음식은 맛이 없다고 생각합니다.
examples.romaji: Heunhi saramdeureun geonganghan eumsigeun masi eopdago saenggakhabnida.
examples.en: People often think that healthy food is tasteless.
