examples.kr: 한국에서는 혼자 살아가는 사람들을 흔히 '싱글'이라고 부릅니다.
examples.romaji: Hangugeoseoneun honja saraganeun saramdeureul heunhi 'single'irago bureubnida.
examples.en: In Korea, people living alone are commonly referred to as 'singles'.

examples.kr: 우리는 흔히 우리나라 음식보다 외국 음식을 더 많이 먹습니다.
examples.romaji: Urineun heunhi urinara eumsikboda oeguk eumsigeul deo manhi mokseubnida.
examples.en: We often eat more foreign food than our country's food.

examples.kr: 봄이 오면 흔히 피는 꽃으로 벚꽃이 많이 알려져 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Bomi omyeon heunhi pineun kkot-euro beotkkochi manhi allyeojyeo issseubnida.
examples.en: Cherry blossoms are commonly known to bloom when spring comes.

title: ~이/히다 [i/hida] (To become)
short_explanation: Used to express a change into a different state or condition; 'to become'.
long_explanation: '~이/히다 [i/hida]' is a grammar point in Korean that is used to indicate a change in the state or condition of a subject, akin to 'become' in English. This form is often used when expressing a transformation, transition or evolution of one state to another. It is important to note that there is a transformational process that takes place before the desired or completed state is achieved.

examples.kr: 날씨가 덥다가 갑자기 춥게 되었어요, 그래서 모두 감기에 걸렸어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga deopdaga gapjagi chupge doeeosseoyo, geuraeseo modu gamgie geollyeoteoyo.
examples.en: The weather suddenly became cold after being hot, so everyone caught a cold.

examples.kr: 그녀는 열심히 공부해서 세계에서 가장 젊은 교수가 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun yeolsimhi gongbuhaseo segyeeseo gajang jeolmeun gyosuga doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: She studied hard to become the youngest professor in the world.

examples.kr: 나의 친구는 한국어를 배워서 번역가가 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Na-ui chinguneun hangugeoreul baewoseo beonyeokgaga doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: My friend studied Korean and became a translator.

examples.kr: 자그마했던 새끼 고양이가 큰 고양이가 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Jageumahaessdeon saekki goyangiga keun goyangiga doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: The tiny kitten became a big cat.

title: ~잖다 [janda] (You know, isn't it)
short_explanation: Used to state information the speaker assumes the listener already knows.
long_explanation: '~잖다 [janda]' is a sentence-ending phrase used to indicate the speaker's assumption that the listener is already aware of the information being shared. It's akin to saying 'you know' or 'isn’t it' in English. This grammar point is used to either confirm information or to imply that the listener should be aware of something.

examples.kr: 너 오늘 학교 가야 하잖아, 왜 아직도 놀고 있어?
examples.romaji: Neo oneul hakgyo gaya hajanha, wae ajikdo nolgo isseo?
examples.en: You have to go to school today, you know, why are you still playing?

examples.kr: 우리 내일 시험이 있잖아. 그래서 오늘 공부하려고.
examples.romaji: Uri naeil siheomi issjanha. Geuraeseo oneul gongbuharyeogo.
examples.en: We have a test tomorrow, you know. So, I plan to study today.

examples.kr: 너 그 사람을 알잖아, 그런데 요즘 어떻게 지내?
examples.romaji: Neo geu saram-eul al janha, geureonde yojeum eotteoke jinae?
examples.en: You know that person, don't you? So, how's he doing these days?

examples.kr: 지금 시간이 늦었잖아, 우린 이제 공부해야 해.
examples.romaji: Jigeum sigani neu-eossjanha, urin ije gongbuhayeya hae.
examples.en: It's late now, you know, we should study now.

title: ~져/지다 [jyeo/jida] (Become)
short_explanation: Used to depict changes in state, emotion, condition, or situation, similar to 'become' or 'get' in English.
long_explanation: '~져/지다 [jyeo/jida]' is a conjugation rule that indicates transformation or change. It can replicate the meaning of 'become' or 'get' as a verb in English. Often used to refer to the changes in state, feelings, situations, or conditions, this form is versatile in Korean language to describe various instances of transformation. This grammatical form makes it possible to denote a process or ongoing change that involves a shift from one state to another.

examples.kr: 날씨가 너무 더워져서 밖에 나가기가 힘들어졌어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga neomu deowojyeoseo bakke nagagiga himdeureojyeosseoyo.
examples.en: The weather has become so hot that it's hard to go outside.

examples.kr: 그녀는 학교에서 인기가 많아져서 많은 사람들이 그녀를 알게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun hakgyoeseo ingiga manhajyeoseo manheun saramdeuli geunyeoreul alge doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: She has become popular in school, so many people got to know her.

examples.kr: 그는 그림을 많이 그리니까 그림 그리는 실력이 정말 좋아졌어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun geurimeul manhi geurinikkageurim geurineun sillyeogi jeongmal joahjyeosseoyo.
examples.en: He has become really good at drawing pictures because he drew a lot.

examples.kr: 일하는데 집중하니까 시간이 너무 빨리 가버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Ilhaneunde jipjunghanikkage sigani neomu ppalli gabeollyeosseoyo.
examples.en: Time has gone by so fast because I was focused on work.

title: ~졌다가 [jyeotdaga] (Was once, but)
short_explanation: Used to express that something was once in a certain state or condition, but then reverted back or changed again.
long_explanation: '~졌다가 [jyeotdaga]' is a complex verb ending used in Korean to represent a sequence of two or more actions or states. It indicates that the subject was once in a certain state or had a certain condition, but then the situation changed again, usually back to the original state. This pattern often appears in sentences implying some form of transition or fluctuation. It is typically used with action verbs in past tense.

examples.kr: 나는 문을 열졌다가 다시 닫았어요. 그런데 친구가 오길 기다릴 수 없어서요.
examples.romaji: Naneun muneul yeoljyeotdaga dasi dadasseoyo. Geureonde chinguga ogil gidaril su eopseoseoyo.
examples.en: I opened the door, but then closed it again. However, I couldn't wait for my friend to come.

examples.kr: 그 레스토랑은 며칠 전에 문을 연졌다가 오늘 바로 닫았어요.
examples.romaji: Geu reseutorangeun myeochil jeone muneul yeonjyeotdaga oneul baro dadasseoyo.
examples.en: That restaurant had opened just a few days ago, but it closed again today.

examples.kr: 아이들은 컴퓨터 게임을 하다가 숙제를 그만두어야 했어요.
examples.romaji: Aideuleun keompyuteo geimeul hadaga sukjereul geumandueoya haesseoyo.
examples.en: The kids had to stop playing computer games and do their homework.

examples.kr: 나의 친구는 직장을 받았다가 한 달 후에 해고되었습니다.
examples.romaji: Naui chinguneun jikjangeul badatdaga han dal hue haegodoeeotseumnida.
examples.en: My friend got a job, but then got fired after a month.

title: ~즉 [jeuk] (That is to say, namely)
short_explanation: Used to restate or explain a point with more detail; 'namely', 'that is to say'.
long_explanation: '~즉 [jeuk]' is a conjunction used in Korean to elaborate or re-explain a mentioned topic or subject in another manner, for the purpose of clarity or noting specifics. It is equivalent to 'namely' or 'that is to say' in English. It is often used when further specifications or details are needed to fully understand a situation, a process, or a term.

examples.kr: 이 연구의 결과를 바탕으로 즉, 우리가 본 바로는 지구 온난화는 인간의 활동 때문임이 분명하다.
examples.romaji: I yeonguui gyeolgwareul batangeuro jeuk, uriga bon baroneun jigu onnanhwaneun inganui hwaldong ttaemunimi bunmyeonghada.
examples.en: Based on the results of this research, that is to say, from what we have seen, it is clear that global warming is due to human activities.

examples.kr: 그는 국제관계 전문가이다. 즉, 그는 세계의 다양한 나라들 간의 문제를 연구한다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun guggye gwangye jeonmungaida. jeuk, geuneun segyeui dayanghan naradeul ganui munjeleul yeonguhanda.
examples.en: He is an expert in international relations. That is to say, he studies issues between various countries around the world.

examples.kr: 이 메일은 너에게만 보낼 것이다. 즉, 너는 이 메시지의 유일한 수신자다.
examples.romaji: I meireun neoegeman bonael geosida. jeuk, neoneun i mesijui yuilhan susinjada.
examples.en: I will send this email to you only. Namely, you are the only recipient of this message.

examples.kr: 그는 내 좋은 친구이다. 즉, 나는 그를 아주 잘 알고 있다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun nae joheun chinguida. jeuk, naneun geureul aju jal algo itda.
examples.en: He is a good friend of mine. That is to say, I know him very well.

title: ~지 않을까 싶다 [ji anheulkka sipda] (I think perhaps)
short_explanation: This construction is used to express an assumption or supposition that something might be. It suggests that the speaker thinks something is likely.
long_explanation: The grammar point '~지 않을까 싶다' is frequently used in Korean to express a speculation or guess that something might happen or might be in a certain way. It conveys a sense of anticipation or prediction. The speaker uses this structure to express their thoughts or assumption about a certain situation, fact, or likelihood. It implies a level of uncertainty but also a level of hopeful anticipation.

examples.kr: 그가 이번 시험에 잘 볼 수 있을지 않을까 싶어요, 왜냐하면 그는 항상 열심히 공부하고 있거든요.
examples.romaji: Geuga ibeon siheome jal bol su isseulji anheulkka sipeoyo, waenyahamyeon geuneun hangsang yeolsimhi gongbuhago issgeodeunyo.
examples.en: I think perhaps he might do well on this test, because he is always studying hard.

examples.kr: 날씨가 나빠지지 않을까 싶어요, 구름이 많아지고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga nappajiji anheulkka sipeoyo, gureumi manhajigo isseoyo.
examples.en: I think the weather might get worse, the clouds are increasing.

examples.kr: 오늘 밤에 집에 도착할 수 있을지 않을까 싶어요, 비행기가 시간에 맞춰 출발했어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul bame jibe dochakhal su isseulji anheulkka sipeoyo, bihaengiga sigane majchwo chulbalhaesseoyo.
examples.en: I think perhaps I could reach home tonight since the airplane has departed on time.

examples.kr: 이번 주말에 영화 보러 갈 수 있을지 않을까 싶은데, 어떻게 생각하세요?
examples.romaji: Ibeon jumal-e yeonghwa boreo gal su isseulji anheulkka sipeunde, eotteohge saenggakhaseyo?
examples.en: I think perhaps we might go to see a movie this weekend, what do you think?

title: ~지 않을까 하다 [ji anheulkka hada] (I guess, I suspect)
short_explanation: Used to express one's conjecture or prediction; 'I think', 'I guess', 'I suspect'.
long_explanation: '~지 않을까 하다 [ji anheulkka hada]' is a Korean grammar point that is used to express conjecture or expectation about a situation that one does not have full information about. It is most accurately translated to English as 'I guess' or 'I suspect'. This grammar point shows the speaker's speculation about a situation and is often used when the speaker is uncertain about the situation.

examples.kr: 내일 비가 올지 않을까 해서 우산을 가져왔어요.
examples.romaji: Naeil biga olji anheulkka haeseo usaneul gajyeowasseoyo.
examples.en: I brought an umbrella because I thought it might rain tomorrow.

examples.kr: 그녀가 좋아하는 사람을 만나지 않을까 해서 신경 쓰고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga joahaneun sarameul mannaji anheulkka haeseo singyeong sseugo isseoyo.
examples.en: I'm nervous because I suspect she might meet the person she likes.

examples.kr: 지금 새벽이니까 아마 모든 사람들이 잠들지 않을까 해요.
examples.romaji: Jigeum saebyeoginikka ama modeun saramdeuri jamdeulji anheulkka haeyo.
examples.en: Since it's dawn now, I guess everyone might be asleep.

examples.kr: 내 친구가 이번 시험에 합격하지 않을까 해서 축하 메시지를 준비하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Nae chinguga ibeon siheome hapgyeokhaji anheulkka haeseo chukha mesijireul junbihago isseoyo.
examples.en: I'm preparing a congratulatory message because I think my friend might pass this exam.

title: ~지 않을래 [ji anheullae] (I don't want to)
short_explanation: This is used when the speaker wants to express the idea that they do not want to do something.
long_explanation: '~지 않을래 [ji anheullae]' is a verb ending used in Korean to express the speaker's intention not to do something. It can be attached to the verb stem, which is directly used in the sentence to express the speaker's intention. It indicates strong will or determination, and implies the speaker has made a decision after considering alternatives. It is less polite than '~지 않겠어요', and can be used in informal contexts.

examples.kr: 저는 오늘 운동하러 가지 않을래요, 몸이 좀 피곤해서 쉬고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun oneul undonghareo gaji anheullaeyo, momi jom pigonhaeseo swigo sip-eoyo.
examples.en: I don't want to go to exercise today, because I feel a bit tired and I want to rest.

examples.kr: 저는 너무 많이 먹었기 때문에 디저트는 먹지 않을래요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun neomu mani meog-eoss-gi ttaemune dijeoteuneun meokji anheullaeyo.
examples.en: I don't want to eat dessert, because I ate too much.

examples.kr: 너무 걱정하지 말고, 그 사람은 제가 대신 말하지 않을래요.
examples.romaji: Neomu geogjeonghaji malgo, geu saram-eun jegadoa daesin malhaji anheullaeyo.
examples.en: Don't worry too much, I don't want to speak to that person instead of you.

examples.kr: 이 옷이 마음에 들지 않아서 사지 않을래요.
examples.romaji: I os-i ma-eum-e deulji anhasseo saji anheullaeyo.
examples.en: I don't like this outfit, so I don't want to buy it.

title: ~지요 [jyo] (~지, right?)
short_explanation: A casual way to seek agreement or confirmation from the listener, similar to 'right?' or 'isn't it?' in English.
long_explanation: ~지요 [jyo] is a commonly used ending in conversational Korean that is used to seek agreement or confirmation from the other person. It is often used in questions, and it makes the sentence softer or more casual, making it a common element of friendly dialogues. In English, this ending can be roughly translated as 'right?' or 'isn't it?'.

examples.kr: 날씨가 매우 좋지요?
examples.romaji: Nalssiga maeu johjiyo?
examples.en: The weather is very nice, isn't it?

examples.kr: 우리는 내일 학교에 가야 하지요?
examples.romaji: Urineun naeil haggyoe gaya hajiyo?
examples.en: We have to go to school tomorrow, right?

examples.kr: 이 영화가 재미있었지요?
examples.romaji: I yeonghwaga jaemiisseotjiyo?
examples.en: This movie was interesting, wasn't it?

examples.kr: 그녀는 아직도 학생인 것 같지요?
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun ajikdo hagsaengin geot gatjiyo?
examples.en: She's still a student, right?

title: ~진행하다 [jinhaenghada] (To proceed)
short_explanation: Used to express the progression or continuation of an action or event.
long_explanation: '~진행하다 [jinhaenghada]' is a suffix in Korean that indicates the progression or continuation of an action or an event. This is equivalent to 'to proceed with' or 'to continue' in English. You can use this grammar point in various contexts including work, study, or simply when talking about progressing through a day or an event.

examples.kr: 연구팀은 이 이슈에 대해 조사를 진행하고 있습니다, 그들은 다양한 데이터를 수집하면서 정보를 분석하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Yeongutimeun i isue daehae josa-reul jinhaenghago itsseumnida, geudeureun dayanghan dateoreul sujibhamyeo jeongboreul bunseokhago itsseoyo.
examples.en: The research team is conducting an investigation on this issue, they are analyzing information as they collect various data.

examples.kr: 오늘 회의를 얼마나 빨리 진행하느냐에 따라서 제 시간에 퇴근할 수 있을지 결정됩니다.
examples.romaji: Oneul hoeuireul eolmana ppalli jinhaenghaneunyae ddalaseo je sigane tuikeunhal su iss-eulji gyeoljeongdoebnida.
examples.en: Whether or not I can leave work on time today is decided by how quickly the meeting proceeds.

examples.kr: 학생들은 공부를 계속 진행하다 보니 시간이 어떻게 지나갔는지도 모르겠습니다.
examples.romaji: Haksaengdeureun gongbureul gyesok jinhaenghada boni sigani eotteoke jinagatneunjido moreugesseumnida.
examples.en: The students were so engrossed in their studies that they didn't realize how the time flew by.

examples.kr: 프로젝트를 계획하는 동안, 우리 팀은 문제를 해결하기 위해 해결책을 진행하고 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Peurojekteureul gyeoghwahaneun dangan, uri timeun munje-reul haegyeolhagi wihae haegyeolgwa-reul jinhaenghago itseumnida.
examples.en: During the planning of the project, our team is proceeding with solutions to solve the issue.

title: ~차라리 [charari] (Rather, instead)
short_explanation: Used to express preference for one option over another; 'rather', 'instead'.
long_explanation: '~차라리 [charari]' is used in Korean language to express when you would rather or prefer to do one thing instead of another, implicating that the first option is the lesser of two evils or a more favorable choice. This grammar pattern is often used when you are faced with two undesirable, negative or challenging options, and you express that you would rather choose the less unpleasant or more favorable option.

examples.kr: 나는 그냥 집에서 혼자 있기 차라리 밖에서 친구들과 놀러 나갔어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun geunyang jibeseo honja itgi charari bakeseo chingudeulgwa nolreo nagasseoyo.
examples.en: I would rather go out and play with friends than just staying at home alone.

examples.kr: 당신이 직접 거짓말을 하기 차라리 솔직하게 말하면 좋겠어요.
examples.romaji: Dangsini jigjeob geojitmaleul hagi charari soljikhage malhamyeon johgesseoyo.
examples.en: I'd rather you speak honestly than tell a lie yourself.

examples.kr: 그 물건을 사지 않기 차라리 돈을 저금하는 것이 낫습니다.
examples.romaji: Geu mulgeoneul saji anhgi charari doneul jeogeumhaneun geosi natseupnida.
examples.en: It's better to save money than not buying that item.

examples.kr: 그럴 거면 차라리 아무 말도 하지 않는 것이 나아요.
examples.romaji: Geureol geomyeon charari amu maldo haji anneun geosi naayeo.
examples.en: If that's the case, I'd rather you said nothing at all.

title: ~처럼만 [cheoreomman] (Just like, as if)
short_explanation: Used to express similarity or comparison; 'just like', 'as if'.
long_explanation: '~처럼만 [cheoreomman]' is a grammar point in Korean that is used to express comparison or similarity. It is equivalent to saying 'just like' or 'as if' in English. It is used to compare one thing or person to another thing or person, or to describe someone or something behaving or appearing as if it were someone or something else.

examples.kr: 그녀는 난 마치 꿈을 꾸는 것처럼만 느껴졌어.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun nan machi kkumeul kkuneun geotcheoreomman neukkyeojyeosseo.
examples.en: She made me feel as if I was dreaming.

examples.kr: 이 음식은 마치 엄마가 만든 것처럼만 맛있어요.
examples.romaji: I eumsikeun machi eommaga mandeun geotcheoreomman masisseoyo.
examples.en: This food tastes just like the one my mother makes.

examples.kr: 오늘은 날씨가 봄처럼만 따뜻해요.
examples.romaji: Oneuleun nalssiga bomcheoreomman ttatteushaeyo.
examples.en: The weather today is warm just like spring.

examples.kr: 그는 마치 나를 알아보는 것처럼만 쳐다보았다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun machi nareul araboneun geotcheoreomman chyeodaboassda.
examples.en: He looked at me as if he recognized me.

title: ~케 하다 [ke hada] (To make)
short_explanation: Used to express causing someone or something to be in a certain state.
long_explanation: '~케 하다 [ke hada]' is a verb ending used in Korean to express the action of causing or making someone or something to be in a certain state or condition. The verb or adjective that goes in front of '~케 하다' describes the state or condition that the subject causes. It is often equivalent to 'make' or 'let' in English. Note, the verb or adjective before '케' needs to be in the descriptive verb stem form.

examples.kr: 그녀는 자기 듣기 좋은 음악만 틀어주케 했어요, 그래서 저희 모두 그녀의 선택에 만족했어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun jagi deudgi joheun eumagman teureojuke haeosseoyo, geuraeseo jeohui modu geunyeo-ui seontaege manjokhaesseoyo.
examples.en: She made it so that we only played music she liked to listen to, so we were all satisfied with her choice.

examples.kr: 제가 엄마를 걱정되는 일이 없도록 해야겠어요, 그래서 엄마가 마음 편히 쉴 수 있케 해야 할 거예요.
examples.romaji: Jega eomma-reul geokjeongdoeneun iri eobsdorok haeyagessseoyo, geuraeseo eomma-ga maeum pyeonhi swil su isske haeya hal geoyeyo.
examples.en: I should make it so that there are no worries for my mother, so I should make her feel at ease.

examples.kr: 그는 아이들이 크는 동안에 자기가 데려다 주지 않으면 학교에 갈 수 없게 했어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun aideuri keuneun dongan-e jagiga deryeoda juji anh-eumyeon hakgyoe gal su eobsge haess-eoyo.
examples.en: He made it so that the children could not go to school unless he took them there while they were growing up.

examples.kr: 나는 방이 어수선해 보이지 않게 침대 위의 옷들을 청소하케 했어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun bang-i eossseonhae boiji anhke chimdaewiui osdeul-eul cheongsohake haess-eoyo.
examples.en: I made the room not look messy by cleaning the clothes on the bed.

title: ~타다 [tada] (To take, ride)
short_explanation: Denotes the action of riding or taking a vehicle.
long_explanation: '~타다 [tada]' is a verb modifier in Korean grammar that corresponds to 'ride' or 'take' in English. It is commonly used with different means of transportation such as bus, taxi, car, bike, etc. When used, it indicates that the subject is taking or riding some means of transportation to a certain destination.

examples.kr: 나는 출근할 때 항상 버스를 타고 회사에 갑니다.
examples.romaji: Naneun chulgeunhal ttae hangsang beoseureul tago hoesae gamnida.
examples.en: When I go to work, I always take a bus to the office.

examples.kr: 피곤해서 오늘은 택시를 타고 집에 돌아왔어요.
examples.romaji: Pigontaeseo oneureun taeksireul tago jibe doraowassseoyo.
examples.en: Because I was tired, I took a taxi and returned home today.

examples.kr: 여동생은 지하철을 타고 학교에 갑니다.
examples.romaji: Yeodongsaengeun jihacheoreul tago hakgyoe gamnida.
examples.en: My younger sister takes the subway to school.

examples.kr: 우리 아버지는 자가용 차를 타고 출근합니다.
examples.romaji: Uri abeojineun jagayong chareul tago chulgeunhamnida.
examples.en: My father drives his own car to work.

title: ~하게 하다 [hage hada] (Make someone do)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used when someone is making or letting someone else do something.
long_explanation: The ~하게 하다 [hage hada] structure is used to indicate that someone is causing another person to perform an action or is allowing another person to perform an action. The action verb is conjugated with ~하게, and the 하다 verb is used lastly to imply the action being caused or permitted. The subject of the sentence is the person who is causing or permitting the action, while the object of the sentence is the person who is being made to do the action.
formation: Subject + (person who is made/let to do something) + Verb + ~하게 하다

examples.kr: 어머니는 저를 일찍 자게 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Eomeonineun jeoreul iljjik jage haetsseumnida.
examples.en: My mother made me go to bed early.

examples.kr: 선생님은 우리를 많이 공부하게 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Seonsaengnimeun urireul mani gongbu hage hatsseumnida.
examples.en: The teacher made us study a lot.

examples.kr: 재수없는 사고로 그는 그녀를 울게 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Jaesueopsneun sago-ro geuneun geunyeoreul ulge haesseoyo.
examples.en: Due to an unfortunate accident, he made her cry.

examples.kr: 그녀는 남편을 행복하게 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun nampyeoneul haengbokhage haetsseumnida.
examples.en: She made her husband happy.

title: ~하여야만 [hayeoyaman] (Only by doing)
short_explanation: Used to express a condition that ‘only by doing something can an objective be achieved’.
long_explanation: '~하여야만 [hayeoyaman]' is a complex construction in Korean grammar that conveys the meaning 'only by doing...'. Essentially, it is used to express that a particular objective can only be attained if a certain condition is satisfied. The sequencing of action or necessity of completing an action to achieve the desired results or intention is emphasized by using this form.

examples.kr: 성공하려면 열심히 공부하여야만 해요, 그렇지 않으면 실패할 가능성이 있어요.
examples.romaji: Seonggongharyeomyeon yeolsimhi gongbuhayeoyaman haeyo, geureohji anheumyeon silpaehal ganeungseongi isseoyo.
examples.en: To succeed, you must study hard; otherwise, there is a chance of failure.

examples.kr: 병이 고쳐지려면 약을 복용하여야만 해요, 그렇지 않으면 건강을 회복할 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Byeongi gochyeojiryeomyeon yageul bogyonghayeoyaman haeyo, geureohji anheumyeon geongangeul hoebokhal su eopseoyo.
examples.en: To heal from illness, you must take medicine; otherwise, you cannot recover your health.

examples.kr: 이루고 싶은 꿈이 있으면 계속 노력하여야만 해요, 그렇지 않으면 그 꿈은 단지 꿈일 뿐이에요.
examples.romaji: Irugo shipeun kkumi issneumyeon gyesok noryeokhayeoyaman haeyo, geureohji anheumyeon geu kkumeun danji kkumil ppunieyo.
examples.en: If you have a dream you want to achieve, you must keep trying; otherwise, that dream is just a dream.

examples.kr: 목표를 달성하려면 계획을 세우고 그 계획을 따라야만 해요, 그렇지 않으면 목표를 이룰 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Mokpyoreul dalseongharyeomyeon gyehoegeul sewoogo geu gyehoegeul ttarayeoyaman haeyo, geureohji anheumyeon mokpyoreul irul su eopseoyo.
examples.en: To achieve your goal, you must make a plan and stick to it; otherwise, you won't be able to reach your goal.

title: ~해서는 안 되다 [haeseoneun an dwae] (Must not, shouldn't)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to express prohibition or things that shouldn't be done.
long_explanation: '~해서는 안 되다' is a common end phrase used in Korean grammar that translates to 'must not' or 'shouldn't'. It signifies things that are prohibited or to be refrained from, and is often used to express restrictions, warnings, or advice. It can be attached to both action verbs and descriptive verbs.
formation: Verb + 기, 어/아 + 야 (+ 는데) + 않다

examples.kr: 너는 남의 물건을 가져서는 안 된다. 그것은 도둑질이다.
examples.romaji: Neoneun namui mulgeoneul gajyeoseoneun an doenda. Geugeoseun dodukjilida.
examples.en: You must not take other people's belongings. That's stealing.

examples.kr: 아이들은 먼저 숙제를 해서는 안 된다. 그들이 놀려고 할 수 있도록 먼저 공부해야 한다.
examples.romaji: Aideuleun meonjeo sukjeleul haeseoneun an doenda. Geudeuli nollyeogo hal su issdorok meonjeo gongbuhaeya handa.
examples.en: Children must not do their homework first. They should study first so they can play.

examples.kr: 당신은 늦게 자서는 안 된다. 건강을 해칠 수 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Dangsin-eun neutge jaseoneun an doenda. Geongangeul haechil su issseubnida.
examples.en: You should not stay up late. It can harm your health.

examples.kr: 우리는 문제를 무시해서는 안 된다. 대신, 우리는 그것을 해결해야 한다.
examples.romaji: Ulineun munjeleul musihaeseoneun an doenda. Daesin, ulineun geugeoseul haegyeolhaeya handa.
examples.en: We must not ignore the problem. Instead, we have to solve it.

title: ~해서야 [haeseoya] (In order to)
short_explanation: Used to express the necessity or requirement to achieve a purpose or goal; 'in order to', 'so that'.
long_explanation: '~해서야 [haeseoya]' is a verb ending in Korean that expresses necessity or a requirement to achieve a specific purpose or goal. It's similar to 'in order to' or 'so that' in English. The statement implies a sense of needing to work or do something in  particular to reach a goal or fulfill a condition.

examples.kr: 학교에 더 잘 적응하기 위해서야 일상적으로 학교 활동에 더 많이 참여해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Hakgyo-e deo jal jeogeung-hagi wihaeseoya ilsangjeog-eulo hakgyo hwaldong-e deo manhi chamyeohae야 haeyo.
examples.en: In order to better adapt to school, you need to participate more in daily school activities.

examples.kr: 올리는 무게를 더 높이려면, 나는 더 열심히 운동해서야 해요.
examples.romaji: Ollineun mugeleul deo nopihalymyeon, naneun deo yeolsimhi undonghaeseoya haeyo.
examples.en: In order to lift more weight, I need to exercise harder.

examples.kr: 회사 직원들에게 좋은 이미지를 보여주기 위해서야 더 많이 야근해서야 해요.
examples.romaji: Hoesa jigweondeul-ege joheun imijileul boyeojugi wihaeseoya deo manhi yageunhaeseoya haeyo.
examples.en: In order to show a good image to company employees, I have to work late more.

examples.kr: 요리를 잘 배우기 위해서야 재료에 대해 더 많이 이해하려면 노력해서야 해요.
examples.romaji: Yoli-leul jal baeugi wihaeseoya jaeli-e daehae deo manhi ihaehamyeon noryeokhaeseoya haeyo.
examples.en: In order to learn to cook well, you have to make an effort to understand more about the ingredients.

title: ~해야겠다 [haeyagetta] (Should, must, have to)
short_explanation: Used to indicate a strong need or determination to perform an action; 'should', 'must', 'have to'.
long_explanation: '~해야겠다 [haeyagetta]' is a grammar point used in Korean to express a strong determination or necessity to carry out an action, conveying the sense of 'should', 'must', or 'have to' in English. It is often used when the speaker has decided to do something based on their judgement or circumstances. This form is commonly used in diary entries and self-talk, and can also be used to give self-advice.
formation: Verb stem + ~아/어/여야겠다 (adjust based on the vowel of verb stem)

examples.kr: 밖이 너무 더워요, 다음부터는 자외선 차단제를 발라야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Baggi neomu deowoyo, daeumbuteoneun jayeonseon chadanjereul ballyagesseoyo.
examples.en: It's too hot outside, I think I should apply sunscreen next time.

examples.kr: 마지막 시험도 끝났으니, 이제 책을 치워야겠습니다.
examples.romaji: Majimak siheomdo ggeutnasseuni, ije chaeg geul chiwoyagessseubnida.
examples.en: Since my last exam is over, I think I should put my books away now.

examples.kr: 열심히 공부했으니, 이제 잠을 자야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Yeolsimhi gongbuhaiseuni, ije jameul jayagesseoyo.
examples.en: I studied hard, so I should sleep now.

examples.kr: 다음 주에 중요한 회의가 있어서, 제 시간 관리를 해야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Daeum jue jungyohan hoeuiga isseoseo, je sigan gwonlireul haeyagesseoyo.
examples.en: I have an important meeting next week, so I must manage my time.

title: ~해야지 [haeyaji] (I should)
short_explanation: Used to express a determination or resolution; 'I should'
long_explanation: '~해야지 [haeyaji]' is a phrase used in Korean to express a self-suggestion, determination or resolution for the future. It is commonly used when you are talking about something you need to do or something you've decided to do in the future. It is also used to give oneself encouragement or determination. Typically, this expression is used in casual, informal speech.

examples.kr: 시험이 코 앞이니까, 이제 공부를 시작해야지.
examples.romaji: Siheomi ko apinikka, ije gongbureul sijakhaeyaji.
examples.en: Since the exam is right around the corner, I should start studying now.

examples.kr: 오늘 밤에 친구들과 영화를 보기로 했으니, 티켓을 사야지.
examples.romaji: Oneul bame chingudeulgwa yeongwareul bogiro haesseuni, tikeseul saya ji.
examples.en: I decided to watch a movie with my friends tonight, so I should buy tickets.

examples.kr: 헬스장에서 오래 동안 운동하지 않았으니, 내일 일찍 가야지.
examples.romaji: Helseujangeseo orae dongan undonghaji anhasseuni, naeil iljjik gaya ji.
examples.en: I have not exercised for a long time at the gym, so I should go early tomorrow.

examples.kr: 오늘 늦게 잠들었으니, 아침에 빵을 사 먹어야지.
examples.romaji: Oneul neutge jamdeureosseuni, achime bbangeul sa meogeoya ji.
examples.en: I went to bed late today, so I should buy bread for breakfast in the morning.

title: ~했더니 [haetdeoni] (After doing something, result)
short_explanation: This form is used when an action is followed by an unexpected result or a change.
long_explanation: The '~했더니 [haetdeoni]' form is used in Korean grammar to express a situation where an action is followed by an unexpected outcome or a significant change. It is usually used when the speaker carries out an action and something contrary to expectations happens as a result. It features a cause and effect relationship with the surprising outcome following the action performed.

examples.kr: 저는 오랜만에 친구를 만났더니 친구가 많이 변했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun oraenmane chingureul mannatdeoni chinguga mani byeonhaess-eoyo.
examples.en: I met my friend after a long time, and he had changed a lot.

examples.kr: 집에 왔더니 청소를 다 해놨어요.
examples.romaji: Jib-e watdeoni cheongsoleul da hae nwass-eoyo.
examples.en: When I came home, the house was already cleaned.

examples.kr: 실시간 업데이트 확인을 했더니 큰 변화가 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Silsigan eobde-iteu hwag-in-eul haetdeoni keun byeonhwaga iss-eoss-eoyo.
examples.en: After I checked the real-time updates, there was a big change.

examples.kr: 전화를 끊었더니 실수로 잘못 연결된 거예요.
examples.romaji: Jeonhwaleul kkeunh-eossdeoni silsulo jalmoth yeongyeoldoengeoyeyo.
examples.en: After I hung up the phone, it turned out that I had mistakenly connected.

title: ~했었는데 [haesseotneunde] (Had done but)
short_explanation: Used to indicate something that was done in the past but has some connection to the present.
long_explanation: '~했었는데 [haesseotneunde]' is a verb ending used in Korean to indicate an action or situation that was completed in the past, but which has some relevance or connection with the present. It also often implies that the expected result did not occur or that something happened contrary to the initial situation.

examples.kr: 책을 샀었는데 도서관에서 같은 책을 발견했어요, 그래서 결국 두 권이 있는 상황이 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Chaeg-eul sasseossneunde doseogwan-eseo gateun chaeg-eul balgyeonhaesseoyo, geuraeseo gyeolguk du gwon-i issneun sanghwang-i dwaesseoyo.
examples.en: I had bought a book but then found the same book at the library, so I ended up having two copies.

examples.kr: 저녁을 먹었었는데 친구가 갑자기 나를 불러서 또 저녁을 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Jeonyeogeul meogeosseotneunde chinguga gabjagi naleul bulleoseo tto jeonyeogeul meogeosseoyo.
examples.en: I had already eaten dinner but then my friend suddenly called me and I had dinner again.

examples.kr: 학교에 일찍 도착했었는데 갑자기 수업이 취소되었어요, 그래서 결국 집에 일찍 돌아갔어요.
examples.romaji: Hakgyo-e iljjik dochakhaesseotneunde gabjagi sueop-i chwisodoeeosseoyo, geuraeseo gyeolguk jib-e iljjik dol-agasseoyo.
examples.en: I had arrived at school early but then the class was suddenly cancelled, so I ended up going home early.

examples.kr: 몇 시간동안 공부했었는데 시험 문제를 모두 틀려버렸어요, 공부한 내용과 다르게 나왔거든요.
examples.romaji: Myeot sigandongan gongbuhaesseotneunde siheom munjeleul modu tullyeobeoryeosseoyo, gongbuhan naeyong-gwa dareuge nawassgeodeunyo.
examples.en: I had studied for several hours but then got all the test questions wrong, the questions were different from what I had studied.

title: ~했을 텐데 [haesseultende] (Would have done but)
short_explanation: Used to express an idea of something that 'would have' happened but for some reason did not.
long_explanation: '~했을 텐데 [haesseultende]' is a Korean grammatical form used to describe an action or state that the speaker assumed would have happened or had been accomplished, but something prevented it from happening. This grammar emphasizes that the course of the action should have followed a certain course according to the speaker or writer's expectation but didn't due to a specific reason or a change in situation.

examples.kr: 저는 원래 오늘 공항에 갔을 텐데, 비행기표가 매진되서 못 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun wonrae oneul gonghang-e gasseultende, bihanggipyo-ga maejindweseo mot gat-eoyo.
examples.en: I would have gone to the airport today but I couldn't because the airplane tickets were sold out.

examples.kr: 그녀는 숙제를 다 했을 텐데, 갑자기 컴퓨터가 고장나서 못 했어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun sujereul da haesseultende, gabjagi keompyuteoga gojangnaseo mot haesseoyo.
examples.en: She would have done all her homework, but she couldn't because her computer suddenly broke down.

examples.kr: 우리는 지난 주말에 영화를 봤을 텐데, 그날 너무 바빠서 못 봤어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun jinan jumale yeonghwareul bwasseultende, geunal neomu bappaseo mot bwasseoyo.
examples.en: We would have watched a movie last weekend but we couldn't because we were too busy that day.

examples.kr: 내가 너에게 전화했을 텐데, 핸드폰 배터리가 다 떨어져서 못 했어요.
examples.romaji: Naega neoege jeonhwahasseultende, haendeupon baeteoriga da tteol-eojyeoseo mot haesseoyo.
examples.en: I would have called you but I couldn't because my phone battery died.

title: ~혹시 [hoksi] (By any chance)
short_explanation: Used to express uncertainty or in polite inquiries
long_explanation: The Korean grammatical expression '혹시 [hoksi]' is used at the start of sentences to indicate a level of uncertainty about what one is going to ask or state. This expression is helpful in lessening the overall abruptness or assertiveness of the conversation, and adding more politeness. Also, 혹시 is used in situations where the speaker wants to propose a scenario that may or may not happen, thereby implying a hypothetical situation.

examples.kr: 혹시 나중에 틈나시면, 우리 같이 커피나 마시러 갈래요?
examples.romaji: Hoksi najunge teumnasimyeon, uri gachi keopina masireo gallaeyo?
examples.en: By any chance, if you have time later, would you like to go for a coffee with me?

examples.kr: 혹시 내일 비가 올까요?
examples.romaji: Hoksi naeil biga olkkayo?
examples.en: Do you think it will rain by any chance tomorrow?

examples.kr: 혹시 그분을 아세요?
examples.romaji: Hoksi geubuneul aseyo?
examples.en: Do you know that person by any chance?

examples.kr: 혹시 시간 좀 있으세요?
examples.romaji: Hoksi sigan jom isseuseyo?
examples.en: Do you have some time by any chance?

title: ~힘들다 [himdeulda] (It's hard to)
short_explanation: Used to express that something is difficult or hard to do.
long_explanation: '힘들다 [himdeulda]' is a common expression used in Korean to depict difficulties or arduousness in doing a certain action, which can equivalently be translated to 'it's hard to' in English. It conveys a sense of struggle, trouble or discomfort, often used in sentences to express physical or emotional hardships or challenges overcoming a particular situation.

examples.kr: 일어나기 힘들었어요, 왜냐하면 어제 밤에 너무 늦게 잤어요.
examples.romaji: Ireonagi himdeureosseoyo, waenyahamyeon eoje bame neomu neutge jasseyo.
examples.en: It was hard to get up because I went to bed so late last night.

examples.kr: 영어를 배우기 힘들다고 생각했지만, 매일 공부하니까 점점 익숙해졌어요.
examples.romaji: Yeongeoreul baeugi himdeuldago saenggakhaetjiman, maeil gongbuhannikkaji jeomjeom iksukhaejeosseoyo.
examples.en: I thought learning English was hard, but as I studied every day, I gradually got used to it.

examples.kr: 건강을 유지하기 힘들지만, 운동을 꾸준히 하고, 잘 먹으면 가능해요.
examples.romaji: Geongangeul yujihagi himdeuljiman, undongeul ggujunhi hago, jal meogeumyeon ganeunghaeyo.
examples.en: Keeping healthy is hard, but it's possible if we exercise regularly and eat well.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 처음 배울 때, 글자를 외우기 힘들었어요. 하지만 계속 연습하다 보니 점점 쉬워졌어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeoreul cheoeum baeul ttae, geuljareul oeuwgi himdeureosseoyo. Hajiman gyesok yeonseuphada boni jeomjeom shiweojeosseyo.
examples.en: When I first started learning Korean, memorizing the characters was hard. But as I kept practicing, it gradually got easier.

title: ~간이다 [ganida] (Used to express that someone does something while doing another action)
short_explanation: Used to depict that someone performs a certain action while simultaneously doing another action.
long_explanation: '~간이다 [ganida]' is a verb ending used to depict simultaneous actions in Korean. It implies that two actions are happening at the same time, typically describing the completion of an action while another is ongoing. This grammar point gives the sense that 'while' or 'during the process' of the first action, the second action happens.

examples.kr: 제가 책을 읽는 간에, 아들이 저를 부르는 소리를 들었어요.
examples.romaji: Jega chekeul ilgneun gane, adeuri jeoreul bureuneun sorireul deureosseoyo.
examples.en: While I was reading a book, I heard my son calling me.

examples.kr: 먹는 간에 티비를 봐도 돼요?
examples.romaji: Meogneun gane tibireul bwado dwaeyo?
examples.en: Can I watch TV while eating?

examples.kr: 그는 달리는 간에 손톱을 물어 뜯었어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun dallineun gane sontobeul mureo tteocheosseoyo.
examples.en: He bit his nails while he was running.

examples.kr: 저는 샤워하는 간에 노래를 불렀어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun shawohaneun gane noraereul bulleosseoyo.
examples.en: I sang a song while taking a shower.

title: ~나다 [nada] (Come out, start to)
short_explanation: Used to express that a phenomenon or state appears or begins to occur.
long_explanation: '~나다 [nada]' is a verb ending used in the Korean language that indicates the start or appearance of an event, phenomenon, or state. It is often used to describe some form of change or new state, it could also be used to indicate emergence or becoming visible. This grammar point is used when something starts to wrong or bad, or something becoming visible or noticeable from an unseen or unnoticed state.

examples.kr: 회사에서 문제가 생기기 시작해서 많은 사람들이 짜증이 나기 시작했어요.
examples.romaji: Hoesaeseo munjega saenggigi sijakhaeseo maneun saramdeul-i jwajeug-i nag-i sijakhaess-eoyo.
examples.en: Problems began to occur at the company, and many people started to feel annoyed.

examples.kr: 진짜 봄이 시작했을 때, 꽃들이 피기 시작했어요.
examples.romaji: Jinjja bom-i sijakhaess-eul ttae, kkotdeul-i pigi sijakhaess-eoyo.
examples.en: When the real spring began, the flowers started to bloom.

examples.kr: 나는 평소보다 많이 배가 고프기 시작했어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun pyeongso boda man-i baega gopeugi sijakhaess-eoyo.
examples.en: I started to feel hungrier than usual.

examples.kr: 우리는 오류가 발생하기 시작했다는 것을 알게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Ulineun oleuga bal saenghagi sijakhaess daneun geos-eul alg-e doeeoss-eoyo.
examples.en: We began to realize that errors were beginning to occur.

title: ~남다 [namda] (To remain, be left over)
short_explanation: Used to express the idea of something remaining or being left over.
long_explanation: The term '~남다 [namda]' is a verb used in Korean to express that something remains or is left over. It addresses the sense of something continuing to exist or stay in place after other components or parts have been removed, used up, or have elsewise disappeared. It can refer to quantities, physical locations, and also to more abstract concepts like time.

examples.kr: 저도 공부하고 싶었지만, 시험 준비를 위해 시간이 거의 남지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Jeodo gongbuhago sipeotjiman, siheom junbiro si gan-i geoi namji anh-ass-eoyo.
examples.en: I also wanted to study, but I hardly had any time left to prepare for the exam.

examples.kr: 결혼식에 초대된 모든 사람들이 도착한 후에는 음식이 많이 남았어요.
examples.romaji: Gyeolhonsig-e chodaedoen modeun saramdeul-i dochakhan hue-neun eumsigi mani nam-ass-eoyo.
examples.en: After all the people invited to the wedding arrived, there was a lot of food left.

examples.kr: 우리는 후천담의 산책로를 다 걸은 후, 더 이상 볼거리가 남지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Ulineun hucheondam-ui san-gillo retreat all dasigeoss-eun hu, deo isang bolgeoriga namji anh-ass-eoyo.
examples.en: After we walked the entire path of the lake, there was nothing more to see.

examples.kr: 그녀가 나가고 나서는 이별의 첫날 밤, 빈 자리가 아무리 커도 금방 채워진 것 같더라고요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga nagago naseoneun ibyeol-ui cheosnal bam, bin jariga amuli keodo geumbang chae-wojin geos gatdeolaguyo.
examples.en: After she left, on the first night of separation, no matter how big the vacant spot, it seemed to be quickly filled.

title: ~네요 [neyo] (Express surprise)
short_explanation: This ending is used when the speaker discovers something new or unexpected, expressing surprise or realization.
long_explanation: The ~네요 [neyo] grammar format is often used in Korean to express surprise, realization, or newly noticed or informed facts. It is used when a speaker's feeling or thought about a situation has changed due to a new information, or when the speaker feels surprised or impressed about something. It takes on the meaning of 'I see', 'Oh', 'Wow', and 'So' in English.

examples.kr: 오늘 날씨가 정말 따뜻하네요, 아침에는 춥다고 생각했는데요.
examples.romaji: Oneul nalssiga jeongmal tattwuhneyo, achimeun chuptdago saenggakhaetneundeyo.
examples.en: The weather is really warm today, although I thought it was cold in the morning.

examples.kr: 그녀가 노래를 정말 잘 부르네요, 이전에 들어본 적이 없어서 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga noraereul jeongmal jal bureuneyo, ijeone deureobon jeogi eopseoseo moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: She sings really well, I didn't know since I've never heard her sing before.

examples.kr: 와, 이 케이크가 정말 맛있네요, 처음 먹어보는 맛이에요.
examples.romaji: Wa, i keikeuga jeongmal masitneyo, cheoeum meogeoboneun masieyo.
examples.en: Wow, this cake is really delicious, it's a taste I'm trying for the first time.

examples.kr: 어, 비가 오네요, 우산을 가져왔어야 했어요.
examples.romaji: Uh, biga oneyo, usaneul gajyeowasseoya haesseoyo.
examples.en: Oh, it’s raining. I should have brought an umbrella.

title: ~다고 [dago] (Saying that)
short_explanation: Used to indirectly report what someone said, thought, or felt; 'saying that'.
long_explanation: ~다고 [dago] is a grammar point in Korean used to indirectly quote or report what one said, thought, or felt. It is equivalent to 'saying that' in English. In sentences, it is used to represent reported speech, thoughts, or emotions.

examples.kr: 그는 내가 밥을 먹었다고 생각했어요, 하지만 저는 아직 밥을 먹지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun naega babeul meogeossdago saenggakhaesseoyo, hajiman jeoneun ajik babeul meokji anhasseoyo.
examples.en: He thought that I had eaten, but I have not eaten yet.

examples.kr: 친구가 오늘은 비가 온다고 말했어요, 그래서 나는 우산을 가져왔어요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga oneureun biga ondago malhaesseoyo, geuraeseo naneun usaneul gajyeowasseoyo.
examples.en: My friend said that it would rain today, so I brought an umbrella.

examples.kr: 선생님이 시험이 어렵다고 말했어요, 그래서 부지런히 공부했어요.
examples.romaji: Seonsaengnimi siheomi eoryeopdago malhaesseoyo, geuraeseo bujireonhi gongbuhaesseoyo.
examples.en: The teacher said the test would be difficult, so I studied diligently.

examples.kr: 엄마가 오늘 밤 늦게 들어오지 마라고 말했어요.
examples.romaji: Eommaga oneul bam neujge deureooji marago malhaesseoyo.
examples.en: My mom said not to come home late tonight.

title: ~다는 [daneun] (The fact that)
short_explanation: Used to denote the fact or idea that  something has been stated or quoted.
long_explanation: '~다는 [daneun]' is a Korean language structure used to express the fact or idea that something has been mentioned or quoted. This grammar point is usually used when conveying information heard from someone or somewhere else. The particle '는' is added after a direct or indirect quote to emphasise that the preceding clause is the content of what was stated or known.

examples.kr: 그는 자신의 실수를 인정한다는 것은 얼마나 어려운지 모릅니다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun jasinui silsureul injeonghandaneun geoseun eolmana eoryeounji moreumneeda
examples.en: He doesn't know how hard it is to admit his mistakes.

examples.kr: 나는 내가 그녀를 사랑한다는 것을 처음으로 깨달았다.
examples.romaji: Naneun naega geunyeoreul saranghandaneun geoseul cheoeumeuro kkaedaraessda.
examples.en: I realized for the first time that I love her.

examples.kr: 퍼피 님의 회사가 본격적으로 확장한다는 소식을 들었어요.
examples.romaji: Peopi nimui hoesaga bongyeokjeogeuro hwakjanghandaneun sosigeul deureosseoyo.
examples.en: I heard that Puppy’s company is seriously expanding.

examples.kr: 오늘 아침에 너가 오늘 결혼한데다는 사실을 들었어.
examples.romaji: Oneul achime neogah oneul gyeolhonhandaneun sasileul deureosseo.
examples.en: This morning, I heard that you are getting married today.

title: ~다면서요 [damyeonseyo] (Said that)
short_explanation: Used when quoting someone's words or delivering what someone has heard from others
long_explanation: '~다면서요 [damyeonseyo]' is a phrase commonly used to indicate a piece of information or thought that the speaker has obtained from someone else. It is a form of indirect quotation in which the speaker lets the listener be aware that the information comes from a different source. The phrase is a combinatory expression created using the declarative form of a sentence ending with '-다' and the quote marker '면서'.

examples.kr: 영희가 서울에 살고 있다면서요, 정말 그런건지 알 수가 없어요.
examples.romaji: Yeong-heega seoul-e salgo itdamyeonseyo, jeongmal geureongeonji al suga eobseoyo.
examples.en: You said that Young Hee lives in Seoul, but I really can't confirm if that's true.

examples.kr: 집에 일찍 돌아오라고 했다면서요, 그런데 왜 아직도 안 와요?
examples.romaji: Jib-e iljjik dorao-ra-go haetdamyeonseyo, geureonde wae ajik-do an wa-yo?
examples.en: You said to come home early, but why haven't you come yet?

examples.kr: 친구가 낼 학교에 안 온다고 했다면서요, 아마 아프지 않았나요?
examples.romaji: Chingu-ga nael hakgyo-e an ondago haetdamyeonseyo, ama apeuji anhatnayo?
examples.en: My friend said he won't come to school tomorrow, he might be sick?

examples.kr: 나중에 커피 한잔 같이 할 것을 약속했다면서요, 그런데 왜 연락이 없나요?
examples.romaji: Najung-e keopi hanjan gachi hal geos-eul yaksokhaetdamyeonseyo, geureonde wae yeonlag-i eomnayo?
examples.en: You promised to have a cup of coffee later, but why is there no contact?

title: ~던데 [deonde] (Used to)
short_explanation: Used to express reminiscence or something one used to do
long_explanation: '~던데 [deonde]' is a past tense verb ending used in Korean to indicate something one used to do or the way something used to be in the past. It is often used in a reminiscing context to recall past habits, situations, or states. It is also used to express surprise or disbelief by highlighting a contrast between the past and the present.

examples.kr: 그는 항상 머리를 길게 기르던데, 언제부터 짧게 자르기 시작했어요?
examples.romaji: Geuneun hangsang meorireul gilge gireudeonde, eonjebuteo jjalbge jareugi sijakhaesseoyo?
examples.en: He used to always grow his hair long, when did he start cutting it short?

examples.kr: 내 친구는 예전에는 채소를 안 좋아했던데, 이제는 건강을 위해 열심히 먹는다고 하네요.
examples.romaji: Nae chinguneun yejeonen chaesoreul an joahatdeonde, ijeneun geongangeul wihae yeolsimhi meokneundago haneyo.
examples.en: My friend used to dislike vegetables, but now they say that they eat them diligently for health.

examples.kr: 나는 어릴 때 청소를 정말 싫어했던데, 이제는 좋아해서 매일 하는 편이에요.
examples.romaji: Naneun eoril ttae cheongsoeul jeongmal sirheohatdeonde, ijeneun joahaseo maeil haneun pyeonieyo.
examples.en: I used to really hate cleaning when I was young, but now I like it and do it every day.

examples.kr: 우리는 어렸을 때부터 함께 공부하던데, 지금은 각자 다른 대학교에 다녀요.
examples.romaji: Urineun eoryeosseul ttabuteo hamkke gongbuhadeonde, jigeumeun gakja dareun daehakgyoe danyeoyo.
examples.en: We used to study together from when we were young, but now we each attend different universities.

title: ~던지 [deonji] (Whether)
short_explanation: Expresses uncertainty or indifference; 'whether or not'.
long_explanation: In Korean language, the grammar point '던지 [deonji]' is often used to express indifference or uncertainty. It roughly translates to 'whether or not' in English and is used to denote that the speaker does not have a strong preference towards the choices in context or does not have a clear idea of the situation. This form is often followed by a question word, and the question word loses its question function.

examples.kr: 너가 그런 의사든지 아닌지 나에게는 상관없어.
examples.romaji: Neoga geureon uisadeunji aninji na-e-geneun sang-gwan-eobs-eo.
examples.en: Whether or not you have such intentions is none of my concern.

examples.kr: 그녀가 올건지 안올건지 모르겠다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga olgeonji an olgeonji moreugessda.
examples.en: I don't know whether she will come or not.

examples.kr: 내일 비가 올지 말지 전혀 몰라.
examples.romaji: Naeil biga olji malji jeonhyeo molla.
examples.en: I have no idea whether or not it will rain tomorrow.

examples.kr: 그는 수영을 잘하는지 못하는지 나는 알 수 없다.
examples.romaji: Geu-neun suyeong-eul jalhaneunji mothaneunji na-neun al-su eopsda.
examples.en: I can't tell whether he is good at swimming or not.

title: ~도록 하다 [dorok hada] (To try to, to make sure to)
short_explanation: Used to express the intention of making something happen or an effort to ensure something.
long_explanation: '~도록 하다' is a commonly used grammar point in Korean that means 'to try to' or 'to make sure to'. It's used when the subject tries to ensure that certain action happens, indicating an effort or control on the part of the subject to make the event or situation occur. When used with a verb, it implies that the subject is making an effort to fulfill that action.

examples.kr: 우리는 우리의 직원들이 충분한 휴식을 취하도록 해야 합니다. 그렇게 하지 않으면 그들의 효율성이 줄어들 수 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Urineun uriui jikwon-deuri chungbunhan hyusigeul chwihadorok haeya habnida. Geureoke haji anheumyeon geudeurui hyoyulseongi jeur-eodeul su issseubnida.
examples.en: We should ensure our employees take enough rest. If not, their efficiency might decrease.

examples.kr: 생일 파티를 계획하면서 모든 것이 완벽하게 되도록 해야 해요. 아무래도 그것은 아버지의 특별한 날이니까요.
examples.romaji: Saeng-il patireul gyehoekhamyeonseo modeun geosi wanbyeokhage doedorok haeya haeyo. Amuraedo geugeoseun abeojiui teugbyeolhan narinikka yo.
examples.en: While planning the birthday party, I need to make sure that everything is perfect. After all, it's dad's special day.

examples.kr: 반장으로서, 나는 모든 학생들이 숙제를 완료하도록 해야 합니다. 그럼 선생님은 우리에게 불만을 가질 이유가 없을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Banjang-euroseo, naneun modeun haksaengdeuri sukje-reul wanryohadorok haeya habnida. Geureom seonsaengnimeun uriege bulmaneul gajil iyuga eobseul geo yeyo.
examples.en: As a class president, I have to make sure all students complete their homework. Then, the teacher won’t have a reason to be dissatisfied with us.

examples.kr: 고객이 우리의 제품에 만족하도록 최선을 다해야 합니다. 그렇게 하면 우리의 비즈니스가 성장할 수 있을 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Gogaegie uriui jepum-e manjokhadorok choeseoneul dahaya habnida. Geureoke hamyeon uriui bijeuniseuga seongjanghal su isseul geosibnida.
examples.en: We must do our best to ensure the customer is satisfied with our product. By doing so, our business can grow.

title: ~든지 [deunji] (Whether or)
short_explanation: Used to express indecision between two or more options; 'whether or'.
long_explanation: '~든지 [deunji]' is a conjunction used in Korean to indicate a choice or indecision between two or more options. It can be translated as 'whether or' in English, and is used when the speaker is undecided and considering all options equally, or when the exact choice does not matter, as any of the options will give a similar result.

examples.kr: 당신이 들어오든지 나가든지 저는 상관하지 않아요, 중요한 것은 작업이 계속되야 한다는 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Dangsini deureoodeunji nagadeunji jeoneun sang-gwanhaji anhayo, jung-yohan geos-eun jag-eob-i gyesogdoeya haneun geos-ibnida.
examples.en: Whether you come in or go out, I don't care, what's important is that the work must continue.

examples.kr: 비가 오든지 맑은 날이든지 저는 항상 산책하러 나갑니다.
examples.romaji: biga odeunji malgeun narideunji jeoneun hangsang san-chaek-hareo nagabnida.
examples.en: Whether it's raining or it's a clear day, I always go out for a walk.

examples.kr: 당신이 이해하든지 못하든지 저는 계속 설명하겠습니다.
examples.romaji: Dangsin-i i-haedo odeunji mothadeonji, jeoneun gyesog seolmyeonghagessseubnida.
examples.en: Whether you understand or not, I will continue to explain.

examples.kr: 강아지가 짖든지 안 짖든지, 마치 대화를 나누는 것처럼 인사하는 것이 좋습니다.
examples.romaji: gang-ajiga jijdeunji an jijdeunji, machi daehwaleul nanuneun geoscheoreom insahaneun geosi johseubnida.
examples.en: Whether the dog barks or not, it is good to greet it as if you're having a conversation.

title: ~라는 것이다 [raneun geosida] (It means that)
short_explanation: Used to indicate the reason or cause of something; 'it means that'.
long_explanation: '~라는 것이다 [raneun geosida]' is a Korean grammar pattern used to clarify the meaning or reason behind a situation or statement. It converts the previous statement into a cause and states the result or reason. It's commonly used after either a verb or a descriptive verb.
formation: Verb + 라는 것이다 OR Descriptive Verb + 라는 것이다

examples.kr: 그녀가 사진을 찍는다는 것은 그녀가 사진을 좋아한다는 뜻이다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga sajineul jjikneundaneun geoseun geunyeoga sajineul joahandaneun tteusida.
examples.en: The fact she takes photographs means she likes photography.

examples.kr: 그가 항상 일찍 일어난다는 것이다 그는 아침형 인간이라는 것이다.
examples.romaji: Geuga hangsang iljjik ireonandaneun geoseun geuneun achimhyeong inganiraneun geosida.
examples.en: The fact that he always gets up early means that he is a morning person.

examples.kr: 가을이 오면 나무 잎이 노란색으로 변한다는 것이다 가을의 특성이라는 것이다.
examples.romaji: Ga-euli omyeon namu ip-i nolan saeg-eulo byeondandaneun geoseun gaeul-ui teugseong-iraneun geos-ida.
examples.en: The fact that the leaves turn yellow when autumn comes means it is a characteristic of autumn.

examples.kr: 우리가 어떤 문제를 가지고 있다는 것이다 우리가 그 문제를 해결해야 한다는 것이다.
examples.romaji: Uriga eotteon munje-reul gajigo issdaneun geoseun uriga geu munje-reul haegyeolhaeya handaneun geos-ida.
examples.en: The fact that we have some problem means we need to solve it.

title: ~라도 [rado] (At least, even if)
short_explanation: Used to express 'at least' or 'even if'.
long_explanation: '~라도 [rado]' is a grammar point used in Korean to convey the meaning of 'at least' or 'even if'. It is used to describe the minimum acceptable or desirable option from different possible scenarios. It is also used to express hypothetical conditions and to soften statements by adding an element of conditionality. The expression can be used to present unlikely or extreme conditions.

examples.kr: 달 걸어가기는 어렵지만 보라도 하자, 그렇게 하면 거리가 그리 멀지 않아 보일 거야.
examples.romaji: Dal georeogagineun eoryeopjiman borado haja, geureoke hamyeon georiga geuri meolji anha boil geoya.
examples.en: It is hard to walk to the moon, but let's at least look at it, then it won’t seem so far away.

examples.kr: 그는 일하기 힘들다고 했지만 일시키라도 해야 하는게 아니에요?
examples.romaji: Geuneun ilhagi himdeuldago haejiman ilsikirado haeya haneunge anieyo?
examples.en: He said it is hard to work, but we have to make him work at least, don’t we?

examples.kr: 최소한 사과라도 하는게 아니었을까요, 그러면 상황은 좀 더 나아질 수 있었을텐데.
examples.romaji: Choisohan sagwarado haneunge anieosseulkkayo, geureomyeon sanghwangeun jom deo naajil su isseosseultende.
examples.en: Shouldn't she have at least apologized, then the situation could have been better.

examples.kr: 집에 가지 않을 거라면, 연락이라도 해주었어야 하는게 아니겠어요?
examples.romaji: Jibe gaji anheul georamyeon, yeonragirado haejueosseoya haneunge anigesseoyo?
examples.en: If you were not going to go home, shouldn’t you have at least made a call?

title: ~러 [reo] (In order to)
short_explanation: Expression used to indicate the purpose or intention of an action; 'in order to' or 'for the purpose of'.
long_explanation: '~러 [reo]' is a Korean grammar pattern often used to indicate the purpose or intent of an action. It is equivalent to 'in order to' or 'for the purpose of' in English. When attached to a verb stem, it indicates that the action of the verb is intended for a certain purpose or to achieve a specific goal. In addition, this particle can also be used in conjunction with certain noun phrases to indicate the intention behind going to or coming from a certain place.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 배우러 한국에 왔어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeoreul baeureo hanguge wasseoyo.
examples.en: I came to Korea in order to learn Korean.

examples.kr: 그는 책을 사러 서점에 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun chaegeul sareo seojeme gasseoyo.
examples.en: He went to the bookstore to buy a book.

examples.kr: 어머니는 저녁 식사를 준비하러 부엌에 가셨어요.
examples.romaji: Eomeonineun jeonyeok siksa reul junbihareo bu-eoge gasyeosseoyo.
examples.en: Mother went to the kitchen to prepare dinner.

examples.kr: 친구들과 영화를 보러 영화관에 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Chingudeulgwa yeonghwareul boreo yeonghwagwane gasseoyo.
examples.en: I went to the movie theatre to watch a movie with friends.

title: ~려고 하다 [ryeogo hada] (Try to)
short_explanation: Used to express an intention or attempt to do something; 'try to'.
long_explanation: The '~려고 하다 [ryeogo hada]' construction is used in Korean to convey an intention or attempt to do something, often equivalent to the English phrases 'try to' or 'plan to'. It captures the nuance of a planned future action or an ongoing effort. It's important to note, however, '~려고 하다 [ryeogo hada]' does not guarantee the successful completion of action.

examples.kr: 저는 매일 새로운 단어를 10개 배우려고 해요, 그래서 한국어 향상을 위해 노력하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun maeil saeroun daneoreul 10gae baeuryeogo haeyo, geuraeseo Hangugeo hyangsangeul wihae noryeokhago isseoyo.
examples.en: I try to learn 10 new words every day, so I am making an effort to improve my Korean.

examples.kr: 아플 때에도 항상 웃으려고 해요, 그것이 저의 방식입니다.
examples.romaji: Apeul ttaeedo hangsang useuryeogo haeyo, geugeosi jeoui bangshigibnida.
examples.en: Even when I'm sick, I always try to smile, that's my way.

examples.kr: 그는 항상 일찍 자려고 하지만, 항상 실패하고 말아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun hangsang iljjik jaryeogo hajiman, hangsang silpaehago maraeyo.
examples.en: He always tries to go to bed early, but always ends up failing.

examples.kr: 우리는 연습하고 공부해서 공연을 성공적으로 마치려고 했어요.
examples.romaji: urineun yeonseuphago gongbuhaeseo gongyeoneul seonggongjeogeuro machiryeogo haesseoyo.
examples.en: We tried to finish the performance successfully by practicing and studying.

title: ~려는 [ryeoneun] (Intending to)
short_explanation: Used to express a future intention, plan, or aim.
long_explanation: ~려는 [ryeoneun] is a grammar point in Korean that shows future plans or aims, in a sense equivalent to 'intends to' or 'plans to' in English. It expresses the subject's intention to do something in the future, giving off the nuance of intention, will, or plan. It is also used when someone is trying to do something but the outcome hasn’t been decided yet.

examples.kr: 내일 출장 가려는 사람은 저 혼자입니다, 다른 사람들은 모두 바쁩니다.
examples.romaji: Naeil chuljang garyeoneun sarameun jeo honjaimnida, dareun saramdeuleun modu bappumnida.
examples.en: I am the only one intending to go on a business trip tomorrow, everyone else is busy.

examples.kr: 건강한 식생활을 위해 채식주의자가 되려는 사람이 많습니다.
examples.romaji: Geonganghan siksaenghwaleul wihae chaesikjuuijaga doeryeoneun sarami manhseubnida.
examples.en: There are many people intending to become vegetarians for a healthier diet.

examples.kr: 토익 시험을 준비하려는 학생들은 많은 시간을 공부에 투자하고 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Toik siheomeul junbiharyeoneun haksaengdeuleun manheun siganeul gongbue tujahago issseubnida.
examples.en: Students intending to prepare for the TOEIC exam are investing a lot of time in studying.

examples.kr: 제 주말 계획은 코딩을 배우려는 것이지만, 평소보다 더 많은 시간과 노력이 필요합니다.
examples.romaji: Je jumal gyehoegeun kodingeul baeuryeoneun geosijiman, pyeongsoboda deo manheun sigangwa noryeogi pil-yohabnida.
examples.en: My weekend plan is intending to learn coding, but it requires more time and effort than usual.

title: ~로써 [rossyeo] (By means of)
short_explanation: Used to indicate a role or means used to achieve something.
long_explanation: '~로써 [rossyeo]' is a grammar point in Korean which is equivalent to 'by means of' or 'as' in English. This form is employed when expressing the identity, status, or capacity in which the action in the sentence is performed. It is used mainly after nouns and emphasizes the role or way in which something is done.

examples.kr: 제가 학생으로써 선생님께서 알려주신 것을 모두 이해했습니다.
examples.romaji: Jega haksangrosyeo seonsaengnimggeseo allyeojusin geoseul modu ihaehaessseubnida.
examples.en: As a student, I understood everything the teacher explained.

examples.kr: 바이올리니스트로써 그녀는 세계적으로 인정받았습니다.
examples.romaji: Ba-iollinisseuteurorsyeo geunyeoneun segyejeogeuro injeongbadassseubnida.
examples.en: As a violinist, she has gained worldwide recognition.

examples.kr: 나는 엔지니어로써 이 문제를 해결할 수 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Naneun enjinieorosyeo i munjeleul haegyeolhal su issseubnida.
examples.en: As an engineer, I can solve this problem.

examples.kr: 지도자로써 그는 팀을 잘 이끌고 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Jidojarosyeo geuneun timeul jal ikkeulgo itsseubnida.
examples.en: As a leader, he is leading the team well.

title: ~를 바탕으로 [reul batageuro] (Based on)
short_explanation: Used to express the foundation or basis upon which something is derived from or used as reference.
long_explanation: The phrase '~를 바탕으로 [reul batageuro]' in Korean is used when something is based on or derived from a certain foundation or reference. It can be literally translated as 'on the basis of' or 'based on'. It's used when you want to express that some action, decision, or creation has been made relying on a certain piece of information, data, or fact.

examples.kr: 연구 결과를 바탕으로 새로운 약을 개발하고 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Yeongu gyeolgwareul batageuro saeroun yageul gaebalhago issseubnida.
examples.en: Based on the research results, we are developing a new medicine.

examples.kr: 경험을 바탕으로 나의 미래를 계획하고 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Gyeongheomeul batageuro naui miraereul gyehoekhago issseubnida.
examples.en: Based on my experiences, I am planning my future.

examples.kr: 이 아이디어는 과학적인 사실을 바탕으로 생각했습니다.
examples.romaji: I aideareun gwahakjeokin sasireul batageuro saenggakhaetseubnida.
examples.en: This idea is based on scientific facts.

examples.kr: 당신의 의견을 바탕으로 회의에서 얘기할 수 있을까요?
examples.romaji: Dangsinyi uigeoneul batageuro hoeuieseo yaegihal su isseulkka yo?
examples.en: Can I discuss this in the meeting based on your opinion?

title: ~를 통해 [reul tonghae] (Through, by means of)
short_explanation: Used to express the means, way, or medium through which something is done or reached.
long_explanation: '~를 통해 [reul tonghae]' is a postposition used in Korean to express the medium, method, or avenue by which something was achieved or conducted. This grammatical point can be equivalent to phrases like 'through', 'by means of', or 'via' in English. It is commonly utilized in situations where explaining the process, conduit, or tool for achieving a certain result, information transfer, or conduct of an action is required.

examples.kr: 나는 음악을 통해 감정을 표현할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun eumageul tonghae gamjeongeul pyohyeonhal su isseoyo.
examples.en: I can express my emotions through music.

examples.kr: 우리는 이메일을 통해 그에게 이 메시지를 보냈어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun imeireul tonghae geuege i mesijireul bonaesseoyo.
examples.en: We sent him the message through email.

examples.kr: 학생들은 실험을 통해 새로운 지식을 배웠어요.
examples.romaji: Haksaengdeureun silheomeul tonghae saeroun jisigeul baewosseoyo.
examples.en: The students learned new knowledge through experimentation.

examples.kr: 그녀는 연습을 통해 그림 그리는 기술을 향상시켰어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun yeonseubeul tonghae geurim geurineun gisuleul hyangsangshikyeosseoyo.
examples.en: She improved her painting skills through practice.

title: ~만큼 [mankeum] (As much as)
short_explanation: Used to express the amount, level, or extent equivalent to a certain standard; 'as much as', 'as...as'.
long_explanation: '~만큼 [mankeum]' is a postposition used in Korean to demonstrate equivalence in extent, amount, or level with a given standard or reference point. It is used to draw comparisons between two things, implying that they are at the same level or have the same quantity. It can be interpreted as 'as much as' or 'as...as' in English. Through its usage, you can highlight the similarity or parity between two items in various contexts, such as time, quantity, proportion, degree, etc.

examples.kr: 그는 그의 친구만큼 열심히 일하지 않아요, 그래서 그의 성과는 항상 작아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun geui chingumankeum yeolsimhi ilhaji anhayo, geuraeseo geui seonggwaneun hangsang jagayo.
examples.en: He does not work as hard as his friend, so his performance is always weak.

examples.kr: 나는 배운 만큼 가르칩니다, 그래서 제가 알고 있는 것은 모두 다른 사람들에게 가르쳐 줄 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun baeun mankeum gareuchimnida, geuraeseo jegak algo issneun geoseun modu dareun saramdeulege gareuchyeo jul su isseoyo.
examples.en: I teach as much as I learn, so I can teach everything I know to others.

examples.kr: 우리는 우리가 할 수 있는 만큼 최선을 다하고 있어요. 다른 사람들이 더 잘하더라도 우리는 걱정하지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Urineun uriga hal su issneun mankeum choeseoneul dahago isseoyo. Dareun saramdeuli deo jalhadeorado urineun geokjeonghaji anhayo.
examples.en: We are doing our best as much as we can. Even if others do better, we don’t worry.

examples.kr: 여행가서 볼 수 있는 만큼 많은 것을 봤어요. 그래서 많은 추억을 만들었어요.
examples.romaji: Yeohaenggaseo bol su issneun mankeum maneun geoseul bwasseoyo. Geuraeseo maneun chueogeul mandeuleosseoyo.
examples.en: I saw as much as I could on the trip. So I made a lot of memories.

title: ~마저 [majeo] (Even)
short_explanation: Used to express the unexpected inclusion; 'even'.
long_explanation: '~마저 [majeo]' is a postposition used in Korean to express the inclusion of someone or something that is not normally expected to be included in a given situation or context. It carries a sense of surprise or disbelief, similar to 'even' in English. The use of this postposition emphasizes the exceptional or unexpected nature of what is being talked about.

examples.kr: 시험이 너무 어려워서 우리 반에서 학생들중에 천재인 민수마저 틀렸어요.
examples.romaji: Siheomi neomu eoryeowoseo uri baneseo haksaengdeurijunge cheonjaein Minsumajeo teullyeosseoyo.
examples.en: The exam was so difficult that even Minsu, who is a genius among the students in our class, got it wrong.

examples.kr: 집에 늦게 왔더니, 엄마마저 잠들어 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Jibe neutge wassdeoni, eommamajeo jamdeureo isseosseoyo.
examples.en: I came home late, and even my mom was asleep.

examples.kr: 오늘은 날씨가 너무 추워서 동물원의 사자마저 숨어버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Oneuleun nalssiga neomu chuweoseo dongmulweonui sajamajeo sumeobeoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: Today, the weather was so cold that even the lion in the zoo hid away.

examples.kr: 그녀는 너무 유명해서 이 작은 마을 사람들마저 그녀를 알고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun neomu yumyeonghaeseo i jageun ma-eul saramdeulmajeo geunyeoreul algo isseoyo.
examples.en: She is so famous that even the people in this small village know her.

title: ~못하다 [mothada] (Cannot)
short_explanation: Used to express inability or impossibility; 'cannot'.
long_explanation: '~못하다 [mothada]' is a negative verb form in Korean, used to express the inability or impossibility of doing something. This form clearly shows the speaker’s negative value judgment to the situation. The speaker will express regret, disappointment, or a negative emotional reaction by using the negative form ‘못하다’. It's used with action verbs to indicate that the action cannot be carried out or is impossible to perform.

examples.kr: 제가 솔직히 한국어를 잘못 하겠어요, 그래서 계속 연습하고 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Jega soljikhi hangug-eoleul jal mothagesseoyo, geulaeseo gyesog yeonseubhago issseubnida.
examples.en: Honestly, I can’t speak Korean well, so I keep practicing.

examples.kr: 이 비에서 운동할 수가 없어요, 비가 너무 심하게 내리니까 잔디밭이 미끄럽게 되서 움직이기를 못하네요.
examples.romaji: Ibieseo undonghal suga eops-eoyo, biga neomu simhage naelinikka jandibach-i mikkuleobge doeseo umjig-ilul mothaneyo.
examples.en: I can't do exercise in this rain, the grass has become too slippery due to the heavy rain so I can't move.

examples.kr: 내가 웹 개발자로서 이 문제를 해결할 수가 없어요, 코딩 실력이 부족해서 이해를 못하겠어요.
examples.romaji: Naega web gaebeoljalous seo i munjeleul haegyeolhal suga eopseoyo, coding sillyeogi bujokhaeseo ihaeleul mothagesseoyo.
examples.en: As a web developer, I can't solve this problem because I lack coding skills to understand it.

examples.kr: 그는 금연을 못하고 있어요, 담배를 너무 좋아해서 멈출 수가 없는 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun geumyeon-eul mothago iss-eoyo, dambaeleul neomu joahaseo meomchul suga eobsneun geos gat-ayo.
examples.en: He can't quit smoking, it seems like he can't stop because he likes cigarettes too much.

title: ~바라다 [barada] (Hope to)
short_explanation: Used to express the speaker's hope or wish for something.
long_explanation: '~바라다 [barada]' is a conjugation used in Korean to express an individual's hope or wish. It is placed after a verb stem to convey that the speaker anticipates, looks forward to, or hopes for something to happen. It often reflects the speaker's desire in the present for a future situation.

examples.kr: 저는 당신이 사업에서 성공하기를 바라요, 정말로 당신의 노력이 결실을 맺기를 바라요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun dangsin-i sa-eob-eseo seong-gonghagil barayo, jeongmallo dangsin-ui noryeog-i gyeolsil-eul matgigil barayo.
examples.en: I hope you succeed in your business, I really hope that your efforts bear fruit.

examples.kr: 우리 모두가 건강하게 살아가기를 바라는 부모님의 마음을 이해할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Uri moduga geonganghage sal-agagil bara-neun bu-mo-nim-ui ma-eum-eul ihaehal su iss-eoyo.
examples.en: I understand the feelings of parents who wish for all of us to live healthily.

examples.kr: 교수님이 저에게 대학원에 진학하기를 바라셨어요, 그러나 저는 아직 준비가 안 돼 있어요.
examples.romaji: Gyo-su nim-i jeo-ege dae-hak-won-e jin-hak-hagil bara-syeoss-eoyo, geu-reo-na jeo-neun a-jik jun-bi-ga an dwae iss-eoyo.
examples.en: The professor wished for me to go to grad school, but I'm not ready yet.

examples.kr: 난 한국어를 유창하게 말하게 될 것이라고 바라지만, 아직 많이 배워야 돼요.
examples.romaji: Nan han-gug-eo-reul yu-chang-hage mal-hage doel geos-i-rago barajiman, a-jik manh-i bae-woya dwae-yo.
examples.en: I hope to speak Korean fluently, but I still have a lot to learn.

title: ~밖에 [bakke] (Only, nothing but)
short_explanation: Used to express limitation, nothing but, only or except.
long_explanation: '~밖에 [bakke]' is a postposition used in Korean to indicate that there is nothing else besides the mentioned subject or object. It gives the meaning of 'only', 'nothing but', or 'except'. It is often used with negative sentences and gives the sense of limitation.

examples.kr: 나는 커피밖에 마시지 않아요, 다른 음료는 전혀 마시지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Naneun keopibakke masiji anhayo, dareun eumryoneun jeonhyeo masiji anhayo.
examples.en: I only drink coffee, I do not drink any other beverages at all.

examples.kr: 이 문제를 해결할 수 있는 사람은 저밖에 없어요, 다른 사람들은 전혀 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: I munjeleul haegyeolhal su issneun sarameun jeobakke eopseoyo, dareun saramdeuleun jeonhyeo moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: I am the only one who can solve this problem, other people do not know at all.

examples.kr: 그는 치킨밖에 안 먹어서 다른 음식을 먹을 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun chikinbakke an meogeoseo dareun eumsikeul meogeul su eopseoyo.
examples.en: He eats nothing but chicken so he can't eat other food.

examples.kr: 이게 남은 마지막 기회밖에 없어서 공부를 더 열심히 해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Ige nameun majimak gihoebakke eopseoseo gongbureul deo yeolsimhi haeya haeyo.
examples.en: This is the only last chance left so I have to study harder.

title: ~본 [bon] (Having experienced)
short_explanation: Used to express the speaker's experience of an action or a situation.
long_explanation: '~본 [bon]' is a grammar point used to describe the experience of the speaker. It creates a sense of having done something or having undergone a particular situation in the past. It is usually attached to action verbs and implies that the speaker has had the experience of performing that action or being in that situation before. It is typically used when expressing personal experiences or anecdotes.

examples.kr: 전 한국어 공부하본 사람으로서 한국어 문법을 가르치는 것이 저의 목표입니다.
examples.romaji: Jeon hangugeo gongbuhabon saram-euroseo hangugeo beop-eul gareuchineun geosi jeoui mogpyoibnida.
examples.en: As someone who has studied Korean, my goal is to teach Korean grammar.

examples.kr: 외국에서 살아본 친구가 생각보다 많아서 행복하다.
examples.romaji: Oegukeseo sarabon chingu ga saenggakboda manhaseo haengbokhada.
examples.en: I am happy because I have more friends who have lived abroad than I thought.

examples.kr: 코트를 샀는데, 이런 코트는 첨으로 입어본다.
examples.romaji: Koteu-reul satsneunde, ireon koteuneun ceom-euro ibeobonda.
examples.en: I bought a coat, it's the first time I'm wearing such a type of coat.

examples.kr: 그리스에 가본 사람이라면 아테네는 꼭 가봐야 할 도시라고 말할 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Geuriseue gabon saramiramyeon ateneuneun ggok gabwaya hal dosirago malhal geosibnida.
examples.en: If you have been to Greece, you would say Athens is a city that you must visit.

title: ~부터가 [buteoga] (Starting from)
short_explanation: Indicates that the occurrence of the action or status starts from a certain point, time, or place.
long_explanation: '부터가 [buteoga]' is a combination of '부터 - starting from' and '가 - subject particle' and emphasizes the beginning of an action or state. If an action or state is specifically expected to start at a certain moment, place or from an individual, then this grammar point is used. This is often used to emphasize that it is from a certain point that things start as per the speaker's expectation.

examples.kr: 나는 아침마다 강의를 듣기 시작하는데, 오늘부터가 진짜 힘듦을 느꼈어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun achimmaeda gangeureul deudgi sijakhaneunde, oneulbuteoga jinjja himdeumeul neukkyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I start listening to lectures every morning, and starting from today, I really felt the hardship.

examples.kr: 사랑은 처음부터가 아니라, 서로를 이해하게되는 순간부터 시작한다.
examples.romaji: Sarangeun cheoeumbuteoga anira, seororeul ihaehagedoeneun sunganbuteo sijakanda.
examples.en: Love doesn't start from the very beginning, but from the moment when we start to understand each other.

examples.kr: 그 일은 월요일부터가 진짜 시작이에요.
examples.romaji: Geu ireun woryoilbuteoga jinjja sijakieyo.
examples.en: That work really starts from Monday.

examples.kr: 여름 휴가는 다음 주부터가 시작인데, 이미 준비가 돼 있어요.
examples.romaji: Yeoreum hyuganeun daeum jubuteoga sijakinde, imi junbiga dwae isseoyo.
examples.en: Summer vacation starts from next week, but I'm already prepared.

title: ~뿐이다 [ppunida] (Only, just)
short_explanation: Used to indicate 'only', 'just'.
long_explanation: '~뿐이다 [ppunida]' is a phrase used in Korean to express a sense of exclusivity, akin to 'only' or 'just' in English. It is generally used to describe that there is only the mentioned subject or object, emphasizing its presence by excluding everything else. It is used in situations where you want to emphasize the limit, scarcity, or singularity of the mentioned subject.

examples.kr: 지금 가진 돈은 오천 원뿐이다. 그래서 먹을 것을 사기엔 부족하다.
examples.romaji: Jigeum gajin doneun ocheon wonppunida. Geuraeseo meogeul geoseul sagien bujokhada.
examples.en: All I have now is five thousand won. So it's not enough to buy something to eat.

examples.kr: 나는 친구가 너뿐이다. 그래서 네가 나를 도와주지 않으면 큰일나다.
examples.romaji: Naneun chinguga neoppunida. Geuraeseo nega nareul dowajueo anheumyeon keunilnada.
examples.en: You are my only friend. So if you don't help me, I'm in big trouble.

examples.kr: 방 안에는 텔레비전뿐이다. 다른 가구는 아무것도 없다.
examples.romaji: Bang aneneun tellebijeonppunida. Dareun gaguneun amugeotdo eopda.
examples.en: There is only a television in the room. There are no other furniture.

examples.kr: 제 친구 중에서 누나는 제가 할 수 있는 얘기를 들어줄 수 있을 사람은 나뿐이다.
examples.romaji: Je chingu jungeseo nuna neun jega hal su issneun yaegireul deureojul su isseul sarameun nappunida.
examples.en: Among my friends, only I can listen to the stories my elder sister can tell.

title: ~사이에서 [saieseo] (Between)
short_explanation: Used to indicate 'between' or 'among'.
long_explanation: '~사이에서 [saieseo]' is a Korean postposition used to denote 'between' or 'among'. It is utilized to specify a position within a certain range or the selection between multiple options. When used with numbers, this grammar point indicates a range between two different numbers. For decisions made among many choices, the grammar point is also valid when paired with a corresponding verb.

examples.kr: 어느 색깔을 고를까요? 파란색과 빨간색 사이에서 너무 힘든 선택이에요.
examples.romaji: Eoneu saekkareul goreulkka yo? Paran saekkwa bbalgan saek saieseo neomu himdeun seontae i eyo.
examples.en: Which color should I choose? It's a tough choice between blue and red.

examples.kr: 성수동과 건대 사이에서 카페를 찾고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Seong sudonggwa geon dae saieseo kape reul chat go isseoyo.
examples.en: I'm looking for a cafe between Seongsu-dong and Konkuk University.

examples.kr: 올해 여름동안, 둘 사이에서 결정을 내려야 합니다: 여행을 갈지 아니면 집에서 쉴지.
examples.romaji: Olhae yeoreum dongan, dul saieseo gyeoljeongeul naeryeoya habnida: yeohaengeul galji animyeon jibeseo swilji.
examples.en: Between the two, I have to make a decision this summer: whether to travel or rest at home.

examples.kr: 10살과 15살 사이에서 가장 좋아하는 영화를 선택해야했어요.
examples.romaji: Ship sal gwa sip-oship sal saieseo gajang johahaneun yeonghwaleul seontaekhaeya haesseoyo.
examples.en: I had to choose my favorite movie between the ages of 10 and 15.

title: ~서야 [seoya] (Only after)
short_explanation: Used to indicate 'only', 'only after' or 'not until'.
long_explanation: '~서야 [seoya]' is a compound of the verb ending '-서' and '야', which means 'must'. Used in Korean to express that a certain action only takes place or a certain state is only reached 'after' another action has been completed or a certain condition has been met. It implies that the action or condition must necessarily proceed another action or condition.

examples.kr: 공부를 열심히 해서야 시험에서 좋은 점수를 받을 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Gongbu-reul yeolsimhi haeseoya siheom-eseo joheun jeom-su palpul su isseoyo.
examples.en: You can only get a good score on the test after studying hard.

examples.kr: 나는 집에 돌아와 마셔야 아무런 업무도 할 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun jib-e dorawaseoya masheoya amuron eobmu-do hal su eobseoyo.
examples.en: I can't do any work until I've come home and had a drink.

examples.kr: 그녀는 강당에 도착해서야 그녀가 출연할 것임을 깨달았어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun gangdang-e dochakhaseoya geunyeoga chul-yeonhal geos-im-eul kkaedal-ass-eoyo.
examples.en: It was only after she arrived at the lecture hall that she realized she was going to speak.

examples.kr: 부모님에게 전화해서야 어제 일어난 사고에 대해 알게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Bumo-nim-ege jeonhwahaseoya eoje il-eo-nan sago-e daehae alge doeeoss-eoyo.
examples.en: It was only after calling my parents that I learned about the accident that happened yesterday.

title: ~소서 [soseo] (Polite way to apologize for an action)
short_explanation: Used to express apology or regret in a polite manner; roughly equivalent to 'I am sorry that I did...'.
long_explanation: The verb ending '~소서 [soseo]' is used in Korean to express regret or apologize for an action in a polite way. It is typically used in apologies, often in formal or public settings. It carries a sense of deep and sincere remorse, regret, and desire for forgiveness, and it is mainly used towards someone of higher rank or status to show respect.

examples.kr: 내가 네게 힘들게 하였소서, 이제 나 아닌 다른 사람을 찾아가시오.
examples.romaji: Naega nege himdeulge hayeotssoseo, ije na anin dareun saram-eul chajagasyo.
