examples.en: I am sorry that I have caused you hardship, now please find someone other than me.

examples.kr: 일을 까먹었소서, 너무 바빠서 정말 기억나지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Ireul kkameogeotssoseo, neomu bappaseo jeongmal gieoknazji anhatssoyo.
examples.en: I am sorry that I forgot the work, I really couldn't remember because I was too busy.

examples.kr: 그때 과연 말을 잘못 보냈소서, 정말 죄송합니다.
examples.romaji: Geuttae gwayeon maleul-jalmot bonaetssoseo, jeongmal joesonghamnida.
examples.en: I am sorry that I sent the wrong message at that time, I am truly sorry.

examples.kr: 너무 늦었소서, 지금부터 빨리 하겠습니다.
examples.romaji: Neomu neujeotsseoseo, jigeumbuteo ppalli hagetsseumnida.
examples.en: I am sorry that I am too late, I will do it quickly from now on.

title: ~않게 [anhge] (So as not to)
short_explanation: Used to express the intention of not to do something or avoid a certain situation.
long_explanation: '~않게 [anhge]' is a grammar construction in Korean used to express the speaker's intention of preventing a certain action, situation, or condition from happening, or their purpose to refrain from doing something. This is somewhat similar to the expression 'so as not to' in English. This gramamtical form is typically used with verbs.

examples.kr: 어떤 일이 일어나도 충분히 대비할 수 있게 항상 계획을 세우세요.
examples.romaji: Eoddeon iri ireonado chungbunhi daebihal su issgae hangsang gyehoegeul sewuseyo.
examples.en: Always make a plan so that you can be fully prepared no matter what happens.

examples.kr: 아무도 당황하지 않게 시간을 정확하게 준수해야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Amudo danghwanghaji anhge siganeul jeonghwakhage junsuhaeya hamnida.
examples.en: We need to keep time precisely so that no one is flustered.

examples.kr: 늦지 않게 학교에 도착하려면 일찍 출발해야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Neujji anhge hakgyoe dochakharyeomyeon iljjik chulbalhaeya hamnida.
examples.en: To arrive to school on time, you should leave early.

examples.kr: 자신을 다치게 하지 않게 조심하려면 안전 지침을 따라야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Jasineul dachige haji anhge josimharyeomyeon anjeon gichimeul ddaraya hamnida.
examples.en: To avoid hurting yourself, you should follow the safety guidelines.

title: ~아/어 버리다 [a/eo beorida] (To completely)
short_explanation: Used to express the notion of completely doing something or finishing an action.
long_explanation: The phrase '~아/어 버리다 [a/eo beorida]' is attached to a verb stem in Korean and it is often used to indicate that an action has been completely or thoroughly done, often with a sense of finality. It can convey both positive and negative emotions depending on the context. It adds an emphasis on the completion or the end of an action, and sometimes it implies regret, surprise, or relief. This grammatical form is commonly used in casual and spoken Korean.

examples.kr: 저는 갑자기 발렌타인 데이 카드를 빠르게 만들어 버렸어요, 그런데 매우 만족스럽습니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun gapjagi balrentain dei kadeu-reul ppareuge mandeureo beoryeosseoyo, geureonde maeu manjokseureopseumnida.
examples.en: I suddenly made a Valentine's Day card quickly, but I am very satisfied.

examples.kr: 객실 청소를 기다리다가 결국 나는 그냥 전부 청소해 버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Gaesil cheongso-reul gidaridaga gyeolguk naneun geunyang jeonbu cheongsohae beoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: After waiting for the room cleaning, I just ended up cleaning it all myself.

examples.kr: 나는 돼지고기를 너무 좋아해서 한 번에 다 먹어 버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun dwaejigogireul neomu joahaseo han beone da meogeobeoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: I like pork so much, I ate it all at once.

examples.kr: 농담을 너무 심하게 해서 친구가 서운해 할까봐 걱정해서 죄송해해 버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Nongdameul neomu simhage haeseo chinguga seounhae halkkabwa geokjeonghaeseo joesonghaehae beoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: I made such a harsh joke that I ended up apologizing because I was worried my friend might be hurt.

title: ~아/어 놓다 [a/eo notda] (To have done something in advance)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to indicate that an action was done in advance or as preparation for something else.
long_explanation: '~아/어 놓다 [a/eo notda]' is a Korean grammar point used to express that an action was done in preparation or anticipation for a future event, or that it was done beforehand for the purpose of another action. It’s often translated as 'to have done something in advance or 'to do something and leave it done'. This form is often used in regular conversation and can give more depth to your Korean sentence structure.

examples.kr: 나는 내일 아침에 바쁠 것을 생각하고 오늘 저녁에 아침 식사를 만들어 놓았어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun naeil achime bappeul geoseu saenggakago oneul jeonyeoge achim siksaleul mandeuleo noasseoyo.
examples.en: I made breakfast tonight in anticipation of being busy tomorrow morning.

examples.kr: 시험 준비를 위해 이번 주 동안 모든 강의 노트를 미리 쓰고 놓았어요.
examples.romaji: Siheom junbireul wihae ibeon ju dongan modeun gangui noteureul miri sseo noasseoyo.
examples.en: I wrote all my lecture notes in advance this week to prepare for the exam.

examples.kr: 우리는 피서 가기 전에 집안 청소를 하고 놓았어요.
examples.romaji: Ulineun pisoga gagi jeone jipan cheongsoreul hago noasseoyo.
examples.en: We cleaned the house in preparation for our vacation.

examples.kr: 오늘은 친구들이 와서 미리 음식을 만들어 놓을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Oneuleun chingudeuli waseo miri eumsigeul mandeuleo noheul geoyeyo.
examples.en: My friends are coming over today, so I'm going to cook the food in advance.

title: ~아/어 달라다 [a/eo dallada] (To ask for)
short_explanation: Used to make a request or ask someone to do something
long_explanation: ~아/어 달라다 [a/eo dallada]' is a conjugated form of '달라하다', which is used when making a request or asking someone to do something for the speaker. This pattern is created by conjugating the verb in the 아/어 form depending on the verb stem and then adding 달라다.

examples.kr: 제 친구가 매우 배가 고파서, '빨리 밥을 줘 달라'고 말했어요.
examples.romaji: Je chinguga maeu baega gopaseo, 'ppalli babeul jwo dalla'go malhaesseoyo.
examples.en: My friend was very hungry, so he asked me to 'give him food quickly'.

examples.kr: 머리가 너무 아파서, '약 좀 주어 달라'고 요청했어요.
examples.romaji: Meoriga neomu apaseo, 'yak jom jueo dalla'go yocheonghaesseoyo.
examples.en: I had a severe headache, so I asked them to 'please give me some medicine'.

examples.kr: 집이 너무 더워서, '에어컨 좀 틀어 달라'고 부탁했어요.
examples.romaji: Jibi neomu deoweoseo, 'eokon jom teureo dalla'go butakhaesseoyo.
examples.en: It was so hot in the house, so I asked them to 'please turn on the air conditioner'.

examples.kr: 커피가 너무 많아서, '한 잔만 와 달라'고 말했어요.
examples.romaji: Keopiga neomu manhaseo, 'han janman wa dalla'go malhaesseoyo.
examples.en: There was too much coffee, so I asked for 'only one cup'.

title: ~아/어 대다 [a/eo daeda] (To do aimlessly)
short_explanation: Used to indicate actions done without thinking or considered as idle activity.
long_explanation: '~아/어 대다 [a/eo daeda]' is a verb ending used in Korean to convey the meaning of doing something aimlessly, without thinking, or without a clear purpose. It is used when someone is engaged in some activity idly or without a clear goal, or when one is preoccupied with repetitive and time-consuming yet unproductive actions.

examples.kr: 제가 그냥 막 쇼핑을 하다 대다 결국 비싼 옷을 샀어요.
examples.romaji: Jega geunyang mak syoping-eul hada daeda gyeolguk bissan os-eul sass-eoyo.
examples.en: I was shopping around aimlessly and ended up buying expensive clothes.

examples.kr: 시험기간이지만 그는 그냥 책을 들여다보다 대다 시간을 다 보냈어요.
examples.romaji: Siheomgiganijiman geuneun geunyang chaeg-eul deulyeodaboda daeda sigan-eul da bonaess-eoyo.
examples.en: Even though it's the exam period, he just idly looked at his books and passed the time.

examples.kr: 소리를 들으면서 그녀는 그냥 거리를 걷다 대다 음식점을 놓쳤어요.
examples.romaji: Soli leul deul-eumyeonseo geunyeoneun geunyang geoli leul geotda daeda eumsikjeom-eul nohchyeoss-eoyo.
examples.en: While listening to music, she was aimlessly walking down the street and missed the restaurant.

examples.kr: 나는 지루해서 그냥 인터넷을 서핑하다 대다 알게 된 사이트에서 책을 구입했다.
examples.romaji: Naneun jiluhaeseo geunyang inteonet-eul seopinghada daeda alge doen saiteu-eseo chaeg-eul gu-ibhaetda.
examples.en: Bored, I was aimlessly surfing the internet and ended up buying a book from a site I found.

title: ~아/어 보이다 [a/eo boida] (To seem, appear)
short_explanation: Used to express that something seems to be or appears to be a certain way.
long_explanation: The grammar point '~아/어 보이다 [a/eo boida]' is often used to indicate an appearance, condition or state that seems to be a certain way according to the speaker's opinion or judgment. This is often used to describe perceptions, assessments or contrasts based on external appearance or situation. It basically means 'looks like, seems like, appears as' in English.

examples.kr: 그 여자는 매우 행복해 보이는데, 실제로는 아마 막대한 스트레스를 받고 있을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Geu yeojaneun maeu haengbokhae boineunde, siljero-neun ama makdaehan seuteureseuleul badgo isseul geos gatayo.
examples.en: That woman seems to be very happy, but in reality, she is probably under a lot of stress.

examples.kr: 오늘은 날씨가 참 좋아 보이네요, 외출하기에 좋은 날인 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Oneuleun nalssiga cham joah boineyo, oechulhagi-e joheun narin geos gatayo
examples.en: The weather seems to be really nice today, it seems to be a good day to go out.

examples.kr: 이 케이크는 달해 보이지만, 실제로는 그렇게 달지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Ii keikeuneun dalhae boijiman, siljero-neun geureoke dalji anhayo.
examples.en: This cake seems sweet, but it's not actually that sweet.

examples.kr: 나는 피곤해 보인다고 친구가 말했어요, 하지만 저는 그렇게 느낀 적이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun pigonhae boindago chinguga malhaesseoyo, hajiman jeoneun geureoke neukkin jeogi eobseoyo.
examples.en: My friend told me I seem tired, but I've never felt that way.

title: ~아/어 서는 [a/eo seoneun] (Although)
short_explanation: Used to express contrast or contrary expectation; 'although', 'but'.
long_explanation: '~아/어 서는 [a/eo seoneun]' is a grammar form that expresses contrast or contrary expectation. It is usually used at the beginning or the middle of a sentence, and can be translated as 'although' or 'but' in English. It highlights a certain fact, situation, or action that is unexpected or contrary to the norm or one's expectations.

examples.kr: 날씨가 춥다고 해서는 외출을 안 했는데, 실제로는 그리 춥지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga chubdago haeseoneun oechuleul an haenneunde, siljeroeun geuri chubji anhasseoyo.
examples.en: Although they said it was cold, I didn't go out, but in fact, it wasn't that cold.

examples.kr: 헬스장에 자주 가서는 운동을 열심히 했는데, 체중은 거의 줄지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Helthjange jaju gaseoneun undongeul yeolsimhi haenneunde, chejungeun geojeul julji anhasseoyo.
examples.en: Although I went to the gym frequently and worked out hard, my weight barely decreased.

examples.kr: 열심히 공부해서는 시험을 잘 보려고 했는데, 결과는 좋지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Yeolsimhi gongbuhaseoneun siheomeul jal boryeogo haenneunde, gyulegwaneun joaji anhasseoyo.
examples.en: Although I studied hard to do well on the exam, the result was not good.

examples.kr: 저는 열심히 외워서는 공연 때 잘 했다고 생각했는데, 실수를 많이 했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun yeolsimhi weowoseoneun gongyeon ttae jal haetsdaganeun saenggakhaenneunde, silsureul mani haesseoyo.
examples.en: Although I memorized it thoroughly and thought I did well during the performance, I made a lot of mistakes.

title: ~아/어야만 [a/eoyaman] (Only if/when)
short_explanation: Used to express a condition that 'only if/when' something happens, something else will or can occur.
long_explanation: The phrase '~아/어야만' is a conditional form in Korean, expressing the idea that 'only if/when' a certain condition is satisfied, then can an expected result occur. This grammar point is used to indicate that an action or state is contingent on a condition being fulfilled, implying that without that condition, the action or state is impossible. It's often used with potential and hypothetical situations.
formation: Verb + 아/어야만 (Depending on the final vowel of the verb stem)

examples.kr: 고등학교를 졸업해야만 대학교에 들어갈 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Godeunghakgyoreul joleobhaeyaman daehaggyoe deuleogal su isseoyo.
examples.en: You can only go to university if you graduate from high school.

examples.kr: 그 영화를 위해 꼭 티켓을 예약해야만 볼 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geu yeonghwareul wihae ggok tikeseul yeyakhaeyaman bol su isseoyo.
examples.en: You can only watch that movie if you book the tickets in advance.

examples.kr: 목표를 이루려면 하루하루 열심히 일해야만 해요.
examples.romaji: Mokpyoreul iruryeomyeon haruharu yeolsimhi ilhaeyaman haeyo.
examples.en: In order to achieve your goal, you have to work hard every day.

examples.kr: 거기에 가려면 버스를 타야만 해요, 지하철로는 갈 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Geogie garyeomyeon beoseureul taya haeyo, jihacheoroneun gal su eopsseoyo.
examples.en: To get there, you have to take a bus, it's not possible to go by subway.

title: ~아/어지다 [a/eojida] (To become)
short_explanation: Used to express a change of state, meaning 'to become'
long_explanation: '~아/어지다 [a/eojida]' is a verb ending used in Korean to indicate a change in state, condition or emotions. It is akin to 'to become' in English. The verb ending changes based on the vowel in the preceding syllable, if the vowel is 'ㅏ' or 'ㅗ', you use '아지다', for all other vowels use '어지다'. It is often used to show a transition from one state to another.

examples.kr: 날씨가 갑자기 추워져서 난로를 켜야 했어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga gapjagi chuweojyeoseo nanroleul kyeoya haesseoyo.
examples.en: The weather suddenly became cold, so I had to turn on the heater.

examples.kr: 작년에는 일을 너무 많이해서 피곤해서 쉴 시간이 없어져서 힘들었어요.
examples.romaji: Jaknyeoneun ireul neomu manihaseo pigonhaeseo swil sigan-i eobseojyeoseo himdeureoss-eoyo.
examples.en: Last year, I worked so much that I became tired and had no time to rest, so it was tough.

examples.kr: 친구가 바빠지니까 자주 만날 수 없게 됐어요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga bappajinikkaji jaju mannal su eobgge dwaesseoyo.
examples.en: Since my friend became busy, we couldn't meet as often.

examples.kr: 음식이 너무 많아져서 한 번에 다 먹을 수 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Eumsigi neomu manhajyeoseo han beone da meogeul su eopseosseoyo.
examples.en: The food became so much that I couldn't eat it all at once.

title: ~았/었 던 [at/eot deon] (Past descriptive)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to describe past events or situations.
long_explanation: '~았/었 던 [at/eot deon]' is a past descriptive form in Korean used to describe an event, person, or situation that happened in the past. It is mainly used to describe a subjective memory or a past situation from the speaker's point of view and can be paired with noun to express the past state.
formation: Verb in past tense(~았/었) + 던 + Noun

examples.kr: 제가 어릴 때 즐겨 본 애니메이션 던 쇼를 어제 다시 보았어요, 많은 추억이 떠올랐어요.
examples.romaji: Jega eoril ttae jeulgyeo bon aenimeisyeon deon syoreul eoje dasi boasseoyo, manheun chueogi tteooreosseoyo.
examples.en: I watched the animation show I used to enjoy when I was a kid again yesterday, and many memories came up.

examples.kr: 그는 5년 전에 만났던 친구와 오랜만에 다시 만났어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun 5nyeon jeone mannatdeon chinguwa orae manhi dasi mannatseoyo.
examples.en: He met a friend whom he met 5 years ago after a long time.

examples.kr: 여름에 가봤던 해변에 다시 가고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Yeorum e gabwatdeon haebyeone dasi gago sipeoyo.
examples.en: I want to go back to the beach I visited in the summer.

examples.kr: 저는 학교에서 만났던 친구들과 지금도 친하게 지내요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hakgyoeso mannatdeon chingudeulgwa jigeumdo chin hage jinaeyo.
examples.en: I am still close with friends I met at school.

title: ~았/었으면 좋겠다 [at/eosseumyeon jokgetda] (Wish something had happened)
short_explanation: This is used to express a wish or hope that something had occurred in the past.
long_explanation: '~았/었으면 좋겠다 [at/eosseumyeon jokgetda]' is a grammar construction in Korean that is used to convey a speaker's wish or hope for an event or condition that could have taken place in the past, but did not. It's formed by combining a verb in the past tense with '으면 좋겠다', which means 'I wish'. Therefore, this phrase translates to 'I wish it had' in English. The speaker expresses regret and a hope for a better past, implying that the current situation is unsatisfactory because the desired event didn't happen.

examples.kr: 회사에 보고하러 갔었으면 좋겠다, 그러면 지금 이러지 않았을 텐데.
examples.romaji: Hoesae bogoharerogasseosseumyeon jokgetda, geureomyeon jigeum ireoji anhasseultende.
examples.en: I wish I had gone to report to the company, then I wouldn't be like this now.

examples.kr: 당신을 더 일찍 알았었으면 좋겠다, 그렇게 되면 많은 문제를 피할 수 있었을 텐데.
examples.romaji: Dangsineul deo iljjik arasseosseumyeon jokgetda, geureohge doemyeon manheun munjeleul pihal su isseosseultende.
examples.en: I wish I had known you sooner, that way I could have avoided a lot of problems.

examples.kr: 난 그날 그를 따랐었으면 좋겠다, 그러면 어떤 경험을 할 수 있었을까?
examples.romaji: Nan geunal geuleul ttaratseosseumyeon jokgetda, geureomyeon eoddeon gyeongheomeul hal su isseosseulkka?
examples.en: I wish I had followed him that day, what kind of experience would I have had?

examples.kr: 더 많은 연습을 했었으면 좋겠다, 그래야 내 성과가 더욱 개선될 수 있었을텐데.
examples.romaji: Deo manheun yeonseubeul haesseosseumyeon jokgetda, geuraeya nae seonggwaga deouk gaeseondwaesseultende.
examples.en: I wish I had practiced more, then my performance could have improved even further.
